pages.title: Congratulations!
pages.content:
Congratulations!

You have completed the Falls Prevention Education Application.

Keep this site in mind as a reference in the future, and feel free to re-read it.

Remember: Falls are preventable. Taking small steps today—like checking your home for hazards, staying active, and reviewing your medications—can make a big difference in your safety and independence.

If you have questions that this application does not answer, please discuss them with your healthcare provider.

pages.title: Goals of Fall Prevention
pages.content:
Goals of Fall Prevention

Fall prevention isn't just about avoiding injury—it's about maintaining your independence, confidence, and quality of life.

Primary Goals

1. Prevent Falls from Happening
The best outcome is never falling at all. This program focuses on:
- Identifying and reducing risk factors
- Strengthening your body
- Making your environment safer
- Managing health conditions that increase risk

2. Minimize Injury If a Fall Occurs
If you do fall, being physically strong and knowing how to fall safely can reduce injury severity:
- Strong bones are less likely to break
- Good muscle strength helps you catch yourself
- Knowing safe fall techniques can protect your head
- Quick access to help reduces complications

3. Maintain Independence
Fall prevention helps you:
- Continue living in your own home
- Stay active in the community
- Keep doing activities you enjoy
- Avoid institutional care

4. Preserve Quality of Life
By preventing falls, you can:
- Stay confident and fearless
- Remain socially engaged
- Continue hobbies and interests
- Maintain physical fitness

Setting Personal Goals

Your fall prevention plan should include specific, achievable goals. Examples:

Physical Goals
- Walk 30 minutes daily without feeling unsteady
- Get up from a chair without using your hands
- Stand on one leg for 10 seconds

Home Safety Goals
- Install grab bars in the bathroom
- Improve lighting in hallways
- Remove all throw rugs

Health Management Goals
- Have vision checked annually
- Review medications with doctor
- Attend physical therapy sessions

Measuring Success

Track your progress by noting:
- Improved balance or strength
- Feeling steadier when walking
- Greater confidence in daily activities
- Completion of home modifications
- No falls in the past month/year

A Realistic Approach

What Fall Prevention CAN Do
- Significantly reduce your risk
- Help you feel more confident
- Improve your overall health and fitness
- Give you practical strategies

What Fall Prevention CANNOT Do
- Guarantee you'll never fall (some risk always exists)
- Reverse all effects of aging
- Work without your active participation

Your Role in Prevention

Success requires:
- Awareness: Recognize your personal risk factors
- Action: Make recommended changes
- Adherence: Stick with exercises and modifications
- Communication: Talk openly with healthcare providers
- Patience: Improvements take time

Working with Your Healthcare Team

Your goals should align with medical advice. Work with:
- Primary care physician
- Physical therapist
- Pharmacist
- Occupational therapist
- Vision and hearing specialists

Long-Term Commitment

Fall prevention isn't a one-time project—it's an ongoing lifestyle:
- Continue exercises even after strength improves
- Maintain home safety as needs change
- Stay vigilant about new risk factors
- Adjust strategies as you age

Remember

The goal of fall prevention is not just to avoid falling—it's to live confidently, actively, and independently for as long as possible. Every small step you take toward prevention is an investment in your future health and happiness.

pages.title: How Falls Are Evaluated
pages.content:
How Falls Are Evaluated

Healthcare providers use specific tests and questions to assess your fall risk and create a personalized prevention plan.

When to Get Evaluated

You should have a fall risk assessment if you:
- Have fallen in the past year
- Feel unsteady when walking or standing
- Worry about falling
- Are 65 or older (ask your doctor about annual screening)

Fall Risk Assessment Components

Medical History
Your provider will ask about:
- Previous falls: How many? When? Where? Were you injured?
- Current medications (including over-the-counter)
- Chronic health conditions
- Recent hospitalizations
- Dizziness, fainting, or near-falls
- Vision or hearing problems

Physical Examination

Vision Check
- Visual acuity test
- Depth perception
- Peripheral vision

Feet and Footwear
- Check for foot problems, numbness, or pain
- Evaluate your shoes
- Test sensation in feet

Blood Pressure
- Sitting and standing measurements
- Check for postural hypotension (drop when standing)

Functional Tests

Gait Assessment (How You Walk)
- Watch your walking speed and pattern
- Observe arm swing and foot clearance
- Check for shuffling or hesitation

Balance Tests
- Stand with feet together, eyes closed
- One-leg stand
- Sit-to-stand test (get up from chair without using arms)

Timed Up and Go (TUG) Test
- Stand from a chair
- Walk 10 feet
- Turn around
- Walk back and sit down

Result: Taking more than 12 seconds suggests increased fall risk

Strength Testing
- Leg strength (important for catching yourself)
- Grip strength
- Core stability

Home Safety Evaluation

Some healthcare providers offer home visits to:
- Identify hazards in your living space
- Recommend specific modifications
- Assess lighting and flooring

Medication Review

Your provider will:
- List all medications (prescription and over-the-counter)
- Identify those that increase fall risk
- Discuss alternatives or dose adjustments
- Check for drug interactions

Creating Your Prevention Plan

Based on the evaluation, your provider will recommend:
- Specific exercises for strength and balance
- Vision or hearing care
- Medication changes
- Home safety modifications
- Assistive devices if needed
- Physical therapy referral

Follow-Up

Fall risk isn't static—it changes over time. You should:
- Discuss falls at every doctor visit
- Report near-falls or changes in balance
- Reassess if you start new medications
- Repeat evaluation annually

What to Bring to Your Appointment

- List of all medications (or bring the bottles)
- Details about any recent falls
- Questions about your specific concerns
- A family member if helpful

Remember

A thorough fall risk evaluation helps identify your specific risks so you can target the right interventions. Don't hesitate to ask for this assessment—preventing falls is an important part of healthy aging.

pages.title: Introduction
pages.content:
Introduction

Falls are one of the most common health problems facing older adults, but they are not an inevitable part of aging. Each year, millions of older adults fall, and many of these falls can be prevented.

Why Learn About Falls?

Understanding fall prevention puts you in control of your safety and independence. Small changes in your daily routine, home environment, and health habits can significantly reduce your risk.

What Causes Falls?

Falls rarely happen because of just one thing. Most occur when several risk factors combine:

- Physical changes: Weaker muscles, balance problems, or slower reflexes
- Health conditions: Dizziness, vision changes, or chronic illnesses
- Medications: Some medicines affect balance or make you drowsy
- Environment: Poor lighting, clutter, or slippery floors

What You'll Learn

This program will help you:
- Understand your personal fall risk
- Make your home safer
- Build strength and balance
- Work with your healthcare team
- Know what to do if a fall happens

Remember

Falls are predictable and preventable. By learning about your risks and taking action, you can protect your independence and stay active in the things you love.

pages.title: What Happens After a Fall
pages.content:
What Happens After a Fall

Even when a fall doesn't cause a serious injury, it can have lasting effects on your health, confidence, and daily life.

Physical Consequences

Injuries
Falls can cause:
- Fractures: Hip, wrist, arm, or ankle bones
- Head injuries: Concussions or bleeding in the brain
- Cuts and bruises: May require stitches or take weeks to heal
- Sprains and strains: Can limit mobility during recovery

Important: About 1 in 5 falls causes a serious injury. Hip fractures are particularly serious and may require surgery and extended rehabilitation.

Long Recovery Times
- Hip fractures often require 3-6 months of recovery
- Some people never regain their previous level of mobility
- Extended bed rest can lead to other health problems like pneumonia or blood clots

Emotional and Psychological Effects

Fear of Falling
After one fall, many people develop a strong fear of falling again. This fear can:
- Make you avoid activities you enjoy
- Cause you to limit social interactions
- Lead to weaker muscles from inactivity (which actually increases fall risk)

Loss of Confidence
You might:
- Feel less steady on your feet
- Hesitate to go outside alone
- Worry family members will think you can't live independently

The Cycle of Decline

Falls can start a harmful cycle:
1. You fall → 2. You fear falling again → 3. You become less active → 4. Your muscles get weaker → 5. Your fall risk increases

Breaking this cycle requires action and support.

Recovery Support

If you've had a fall:
- Tell your doctor - Even if you weren't injured, your doctor should know
- Start physical therapy - Helps rebuild strength and confidence  
- Address underlying causes - Review medications, check vision, assess home safety
- Don't isolate yourself - Stay connected with friends and activities

Prevention Is Key

The best way to handle falls is to prevent them in the first place. The lessons in this program will show you how.

Remember

While falls can have serious consequences, most are preventable. If you've already fallen, don't let fear keep you from staying active. Instead, use it as motivation to take specific fall-prevention steps.

pages.title: Who Is at Higher Risk
pages.content:
Who Is at Higher Risk

While anyone can fall, certain factors increase your chances. Understanding your personal risk helps you target the right prevention strategies.

Age and Fall Risk

Age 65-74: About 1 in 4 adults in this age group fall each year

Age 75 and older: Fall risk increases to nearly 1 in 3

However, age alone doesn't cause falls. It's the changes that sometimes come with age that matter.

Medical Conditions That Increase Risk

Balance and Movement Disorders
- Parkinson's disease
- Stroke or history of stroke
- Multiple sclerosis
- Arthritis that affects joints

Chronic Health Issues
- Diabetes (especially if it causes nerve damage in feet)
- Heart disease or irregular heartbeats
- Thyroid problems
- Low blood pressure when standing

Sensory Problems
- Poor vision or uncorrected vision changes
- Hearing loss (affects balance)
- Numbness in feet or legs

Lifestyle and Behavior Factors

You may be at higher risk if you:
- Have fallen before (doubles your chance of falling again)
- Limit physical activity or exercise
- Live alone (help isn't immediately available)
- Have recently been hospitalized
- Use a walker or cane improperly

Medications

Taking certain medications increases fall risk:
- 4 or more medications: Any combination increases risk
- Blood pressure medicines
- Sedatives or sleeping pills
- Antidepressants
- Pain medications (especially opioids)

Note: Don't stop medications on your own. Talk with your doctor about safer alternatives.

Physical Weakness

Signs of weakness that increase fall risk:
- Difficulty getting up from a chair without using arms
- Trouble walking or feeling unsteady
- Needing to hold onto furniture when walking
- Taking small, shuffling steps

Women vs. Men

- Women fall more often than men
- Men are more likely to die from fall-related injuries
- Both genders benefit equally from prevention programs

Multiple Risk Factors

Having one risk factor doesn't mean you'll fall. Most falls happen when several factors combine. The good news: you can modify many of these risks.

What You Can Do

- Get a fall risk assessment from your healthcare provider
- Review this list honestly - which factors apply to you?
- Focus on modifiable risks (later lessons show you how)
- Don't let risk factors cause fear - let them motivate action

Remember

Higher risk doesn't mean falls are inevitable. Identifying your personal risk factors is the first step toward targeted prevention.

pages.title: Why Falls Matter
pages.content:
Why Falls Matter

Falls are the leading cause of injury among older adults, but understanding the impact can motivate you to take simple steps toward prevention.

The Numbers

Every year in the United States:
- 1 in 4 adults age 65 and older experiences a fall
- Falls send 3 million older adults to emergency departments
- Falls lead to more than 800,000 hospitalizations annually

But here's the good news: most falls can be prevented.

Beyond Physical Injury

When someone falls, the impact goes beyond broken bones:

Loss of Independence

- Fear of falling again may cause you to limit activities
- You might avoid social events or stop hobbies you enjoy
- Some people need help with daily tasks they used to do alone

Emotional Impact
- Anxiety about falling can affect your confidence
- Depression may develop if you become less active
- Worry about being a burden on family members

Financial Costs
- Emergency room visits and hospital stays are expensive
- Rehabilitation and physical therapy add up
- Home modifications or assistive devices require investment

Falls Are NOT Normal Aging

Many people think falling is just "part of getting older." This is not true. While some changes happen with age, falls are not inevitable. With the right information and actions, you can maintain your balance, strength, and independence.

What You Can Do

Understanding why falls matter is the first step. The rest of this program will show you specific, practical ways to reduce your risk and stay safe.

Remember

Falls are serious, but they are preventable. Taking action now protects your health, independence, and quality of life for years to come.

pages.title: Introduction
pages.content:
Introduction

Now that you understand your fall risks, it's time to make your home safer. Home modifications are among the most effective fall prevention strategies—and many are simple and inexpensive.

Why Focus on Home Safety?

The facts:
- 55% of falls happen at home
- Most falls occur in familiar places, not unfamiliar ones
- Simple changes can reduce home fall risk by 30-50%

Your Home Assessment

Before making changes, walk through your home room by room:
- Look for hazards you've stopped noticing
- Get down to floor level to see trip hazards
- Test lighting at different times of day
- Ask family or friends for fresh perspectives

The Pay off

Making your home safer allows you to:
- Move confidently through your space
- Stay independent longer
- Reduce fear and anxiety
- Prevent injuries
- Age in place successfully

Categories of Home Modifications

No-Cost Changes
- Removing clutter
- Rearranging furniture
- Improving habits (turning on lights)
- Storing items at accessible heights

Low-Cost Changes ($0-$100)
- Non-slip mats
- Night lights
- Removing throw rugs
- Cord organizers
- Bright light bulbs

Moderate-Cost Changes ($100-$500)
- Additional lighting fixtures
- Grab bars
- Handrails
- Raised toilet seats
- Shower benches

Major Modifications ($500+)
- Stair lifts
- Walk-in showers
- Bathroom remodels
- Ramps

Good news: Most effective changes are free or low-cost.

What This Section Covers

The following lessons provide room-by-room guidance:
1. Living room and bedroom safety
2. Stair modifications
3. Bathroom safety (highest priority)
4. Lighting improvements
5. Helpful equipment

Getting Started

Start with high-impact, low-cost changes:
- Remove all throw rugs today
- Add nightlights tonight
- Clear walking paths this week

Then tackle one room per week:
- Week 1: Bathroom (highest risk)
- Week 2: Bedroom and hallways
- Week 3: Living spaces
- Week 4: Stairs

Remember

Your home should support your independence, not threaten it. Even small changes make a meaningful difference in your safety and confidence.

pages.title: Lighting and Nighttime Safety
pages.content:
Lighting and Nighttime Safety

Poor lighting is a major—yet easily fixable—fall risk factor. Good lighting throughout your home can reduce fall risk by up to 50%.

Why Lighting Matters

Vision and balance:
- Your eyes help your brain understand where your body is in space
- Poor lighting forces you to rely more on balance alone
- Shadows can hide obstacles and create illusions
- Aging eyes need 2-3 times more light than younger eyes

Statistics:
- Most falls happen during transitions (light to dark, dark to light)
- Nighttime bathroom trips are extremely high-risk
- Early morning and dusk are peak fall times

General Lighting Principles

Brightness

How much light:
- Living areas: 100-150 watt equivalent
- Kitchens and bathrooms: 150-200 watt equivalent  
- Hallways: 75-100 watt equivalent
- Stairs: 150+ watt equivalent

LED bulbs:
- Use "daylight" or "bright white" (4000-5000K)
- Avoid "soft white" or "warm" (too dim/yellow)
- More energy-efficient than old bulbs
- Cost: $2-5 per bulb

Consistency

Avoid stark contrasts:
- Eyes need time to adjust between very bright and very dark
- Use transitional lighting (nightlights, dim switches)
- Maintain moderate light levels throughout home

Accessibility

Switch placement:
- Light switches at room entrances
- Never enter dark room to find switch
- Three-way switches for stairs and long hallways
- Illuminated or glow-in-dark switch plates

Room-by-Room Lighting

Bedroom

Critical for nighttime safety:
- Lamp within arm's reach of bed
  - Touch lamps easiest (one tap, on) 
  - Large, easy-to-find switch
- Bright overhead light for daily activities
- Multiple light sources (no single dark spots)

Path to bathroom:
- Motion-sensor nightlights every 8-10 feet
- Plug-in LED nightlights ($8-12 each)
- Should create continuous lit path
- No need to turn on overhead lights

Bathroom

Brightest room in house:
- Overhead lighting: 150+ watts equivalent
- Light switch OUTSIDE door (turn on before entering)
- Nightlight or leave light on at night
- No shadows in tub/shower area
- Mirror lighting for grooming

Stairs

Extremely important:
- Bright, even lighting across all steps
- Light switches at top AND bottom
- No shadows on steps
- Consider LED strip lighting along handrail
- Motion sensors for nighttime

Kitchen

Task lighting:
- Bright overhead lights
- Under-cabinet lights for counters
- Light over stove
- Eliminate all shadows
- See clearly inside cabinets and drawers

Hallways

Continuous pathway:
- No dark stretches
- Nightlights every 10-15 feet
- Overhead lights with switches at both ends
- Motion sensors for nighttime convenience

Living Room

Balanced lighting:
- Multiple light sources (avoid relying on one lamp)
- Reading lights where needed
- No dark corners to navigate around
- Light paths to doors and kitchen

Outdoor Areas

Entry and Exit:
- Motion-sensor lights at all doors
- Well-lit walkways and driveways
- Illuminate steps clearly
- Timer or dusk-to-dawn sensor
- Solar lights for pathways ($10-20 each)

Nighttime Safety Strategies

Motion-Sensor Nightlights

Biggest impact for lowest cost:
- Plug into outlets along bathroom path
- Turn on automatically when you approach
- Turn off after you return to bed
- No fumbling for switches
- Cost: $8-15 each

How many to use:
- Bedroom to bathroom: every 8-10 feet
- 3-5 lights for typical path
- Total cost: $30-60

Bedside Lighting

Options:
- Touch lamp: Tap to turn on/off ($15-30)
- Smart bulb: Control from phone ($10-20/bulb)
- Voice-activated: "Alexa, turn on bedroom light"
- Remote-controlled: Switch by remote ($20-40)

Backup:
- Keep flashlight at bedside
- Fresh batteries  
- Know where it is in dark

Bathroom Options

For nighttime:
- Leave light on (LED uses < $1/month)
- Bright nightlight (10-15 watts)
- Motion-sensor light
- Dimmer switch (lower at night)

Lighting Technology

Smart Home Lighting

Voice control:
- "Alexa, turn on hall lights"
- No getting out of bed to turn on lights
- Can control from anywhere
- Smart bulbs: $10-20 each
- Smart switches: $20-40 each

Automation:
- Lights turn on at sunset
- Turn off at sunrise
- Schedule bathroom light at typical wake time
- Path lights activate at bedtime

Motion Sensors

Indoor:
- Plugin nightlights ($8-15)
- Ceiling mount sensors ($20-40)
- Under-cabinet sensors ($15-25)

Outdoor:
- Dusk-to-dawn lights
- Motion-activated security lights
- Solar path lights

Timer Switches

Automatic control:
- Set lights to turn on before you wake
- Turn off during bright daylight
- Ensure lights on before you arrive home
- Cost: $10-25 per switch

Special Considerations

If You Wear Glasses

Keep accessible:
- Glasses at bedside
- Put on BEFORE getting up
- Consider prescription nightlight brightness
- Don't walk without glasses if vision-dependent

Light Sensitivity

If lights bother you:
- Use dimmer switches
- Warm LED bulbs instead of bright white
- Gradual lighting (nightlights + some overhead)
- Still prioritize safety over comfort

pages.title: Safer Bathroom
pages.content:
Safer Bathroom

The bathroom is the single most dangerous room in your home for falls. Wet surfaces, hard fixtures, and awkward movements create a perfect storm of fall risk. Making your bathroom safer is the highest-priority home modification.

Why Bathrooms Are So Dangerous

Statistics:
- 80% of bathroom falls result in injuries
- Most common injuries: hip fractures, head trauma
- Combination of hard surfaces + water = extreme risk

Risk factors:
- Wet, slippery floors and tub/shower
- Getting in/out of tub or shower
- Reaching, bending, and turning
- Standing on one leg (drying feet, putting on pants)
- Nighttime bathroom trips when sleepy

Essential Bathroom Safety Features

1. Grab Bars (MOST IMPORTANT)

Critical locations:
- Inside shower/tub (at least 2 bars)
- Next to toilet (one or both sides)
- Outside tub for entering/exiting

Proper installation:
- Must support 250-300 pounds
- Attach to wall studs, NOT drywall alone
- Professional installation strongly recommended
- Test stability before relying on them

Positioning:
- 33-36 inches high (grab at body height)
- Horizontal for most uses
- Vertical bars help with standing
- Angled bars (45 degrees) offer flexibility

Cost: $15-40 per bar + $50-100 installation each

DO NOT use towel bars or soap dishes for support—they will pull out of the wall!

2. Non-Slip Surfaces

Tub and Shower:
- Adhesive non-slip strips or decals
- Textured rubber mat with suction cups
- Replace mat when suction weakens
- Clean regularly (soap buildup reduces grip)

Bathroom Floor:
- Remove ALL bath mats and rugs
- If you must have a mat:
  - Use only rubber-backed, non-slip
  - Ensure it lies completely flat
  - Better option: Remove entirely

3. Shower/Tub Modifications

Stepping over tub edge is extremely risky.

Solutions:
- Transfer bench: Sit, swing legs over ($40-80)
- Tub cut: Remove section of tub wall ($500-1,000)
- Walk-in shower: Convert tub to curbless shower ($3,000-8,000)
- Walk-in tub: Door in tub side ($3,000-10,000)

Hand-held shower head:
- Shower while seated
- Better control
- Reduces need to move around wet tub
- Cost: $20-100

Shower chair or bench:
- Sit while showering
- Eliminates balance requirements
- Reduces fatigue
- Cost: $30-150

Toilet Safety

Height Matters

Problem: Standard toilets are too low (causes strain getting up)

Solutions:
- Raised toilet seat: Adds 3-6 inches ($25-60)
- Toilet safety frame: Armrests for support ($40-100)
- Comfort height toilet: 17-19 inches high ($200-400 + installation)

Getting up from toilet:
- Use grab bars or safety frame
- Never pull on sink or toilet paper holder
- Scoot forward before standing
- Take your time

Sink Area Safety

Stability:
- Never lean on sink for support (can break free from wall)
- Install grab bar near sink if needed
- Use wall for balance, not fixtures

Storage:
- Keep daily items at easy reach
- Avoid bending for items under sink
- Use lazy Susan for corner cabinet access

Footwear:
- Never barefoot in bathroom
- Keep non-slip slippers just outside door
- Put on slippers BEFORE entering bathroom

Lighting (Critical for Bathroom)

Requirements:
- Brightest lights in your home
- Light switch outside bathroom door
- Nightlight for nighttime use
- No shadows in tub/shower

Best options:
- Bright LED lighting (100+ watts equivalent)
- Motion-sensor nightlight for nighttime
- Leave light on at night (uses minimal electricity)

Nighttime Bathroom Safety

High-risk time:
- Sleepy and less coordinated
- Tend to rush
- Eyes not adjusted to light
- May be taking nighttime medications

Prevention:
- Motion-sensor nightlights along path
- Keep bathroom light on or very bright nightlight
- Bedside commode if distance/frequency is issue
- Limit evening fluids if nighttime trips are frequent

Door and Layout

Door considerations:
- Should open outward (in case you fall, door isn't blocked)
- Remove locks or use privacy lock that can be opened from outside
- Ensure doorway is wide enough for walker if used

Floor space:
- Remove unnecessary furniture
- Keep clear path to toilet and shower
- No rugs to trip over

Bathing Safety Rules

Before showering/bathing:
- □ Gather all supplies within reach
- □ Ensure grab bars are secure
- □ Place non-slip mat in tub
- □ Adjust water temperature before entering
- □ Put on non-slip footwear

During bathing:
- □ Use grab bars when entering/exiting
- □ Sit on shower chair if available
- □ Take your time
- □ Don't lock the door
- □ Have phone nearby in case of emergency

After bathing:
- □ Dry off while seated if possible
- □ Use grab bars to stand and exit
- □ Wipe up water from floor
- □ Put on non-slip footwear immediately

Emergency Preparedness

If you live alone:
- Don't lock bathroom door
- Keep phone within reach
- Consider medical alert device
- Tell family your bathing schedule
- Have plan if you fall in bathroom

Can't get up after fall:
- Don't panic
- Call for help (phone or medical alert)
- Stay warm (grab towel)
- Don't try to stand if injured

pages.title: Safer Living Room and Bedroom
pages.content:
Safer Living Room and Bedroom

Your living room and bedroom are where you spend most of your time at home. Making these spaces safer reduces daily fall risk significantly.

Living Room Safety

Furniture Arrangement

Clear pathways:
- Create at least 3 feet of clear walking space
- Arrange furniture along walls when possible
- Remove unnecessary pieces
- Avoid having to walk around coffee tables

Stable support:
- Remove wheeled or rocking furniture from walking paths
- Ensure all furniture is sturdy enough to lean on if needed
- Avoid lightweight decorative pieces in high-traffic areas

Floor Safety

Eliminate trip hazards:
- Remove ALL throw rugs and area rugs
  - If you must keep rugs, use non-slip backing AND tape edges down
  - Best option: Remove them entirely
- Secure electrical cords along baseboards
- Arrange furniture to avoid stretching cords across rooms
- Remove floor clutter daily

Carpet considerations:
- Low pile carpet is safer than thick, plush carpet
- Repair worn or loose carpet immediately
- Ensure transitions between rooms are smooth and visible

Seating

Chair safety:
- Chair seats should be 17-19 inches high (knee height when standing)
- Chairs should have arms for pushing up
- Avoid low, soft sofas (hard to get out of)
- Test stability before using occasional chairs

Storage and Accessibility

Daily items:
- Keep frequently used items at waist to shoulder height
- Avoid storing things on high shelves that require reaching
- Use reacher/grabber tools ($10-20) for dropped items
- Don't bend to pick things up if unsteady

Remote controls and phones:
- Keep within easy reach of seating
- Consider cordless phones in multiple rooms
- Large-button remotes are easier to use

Entertainment Setup

TV viewing:
- Ensure TV is at appropriate height (eye level when seated)
- Avoid glare that could obscure obstacles
- Keep volume at level that doesn't startle you

Windows and Blinds

Cord management:
- Keep window blind cords secured and out of walking paths
- Consider cordless blinds

Bedroom Safety

Bed Height

Critical consideration:
- When sitting on bed edge, feet should rest flat on floor
- Knees should be at 90-degree angle
- Too low: Hard to stand up
- Too high: Feet dangle, hard to get in

Adjusting bed height:
- Add bed risers (available at stores, $15-30)
- Remove casters to lower bed
- Consider adjustable bed frame

Bedside Essentials

Within arm's reach:
- Lamp with easy-to-find switch
- Phone (preferably with large buttons)
- Glasses
- Glass of water
- Medications (if taken at night)

Nightstand:
- Stable and sturdy
- Right height (level with mattress top)
- Not cluttered
- Large enough for essentials

Bedroom Flooring

High-risk area:
- Bedrooms have highest rate of nighttime falls
- Remove all rugs, especially beside bed
- Clear path from bed to bathroom
- No cords across walking path

Footwear:
- Keep non-slip slippers or shoes at bedside
- Never walk in socks alone
- Slip-on shoes easier than lace-ups for nighttime

Lighting (Critical for Bedroom)

Bedside lighting:
- Lamp switch should be reachable from bed
- Consider touch lamps or voice-activated lights
- Keep flashlight at bedside for power outages

Path to bathroom:
- Motion-sensor nightlights in outlet along path
- Leave bathroom light on or use nightlight
- Consider smart lights you can turn on from bed

Closets and Dressers

Clothing storage:
- Daily-wear clothes at easy-to-reach heights
- Avoid reaching overhead or bending low
- Use closet organizers to bring items forward
- Consider a dressing chair for putting on clothes

Getting dressed:
- Sit down to put on pants and shoes
- Use sock aids and long-handled shoehorns
- Lay out clothes the night before

Hallways

Clear passage:
- Remove decorative tables or narrow stands
- Keep walls clear of protruding items
- Ensure adequate width (minimum 36 inches)

Lighting:
- Bright overhead lights
- Night lights every 10-15 feet
- Light switches at both ends of hall
- Motion sensors for nighttime

Simple Equipment That Helps

For living room:
- Reacher/grabber tool ($10-20)
- Furniture risers for low chairs ($15-25)
- Cord organizers ($5-10)

For bedroom:
- Bed rails for assistance ($30-50)
- Bed stick or pole for leverage ($40-60)
- Touch lamps ($15-30)
- Motion sensor nightlights ($10-15 each)

Quick Safety Checklist

Living Room:
- □ Clear 3-foot pathways
- □ No throw rugs
- □ Cords secured
- □ Stable furniture only in walking areas
- □ Good lighting

Bedroom:
- □ Bed at proper height
- □ Bedside lamp within reach

Common Mistakes to Avoid

1. Don't keep decorative rugs "because they're pretty"—safety over aesthetics
2. Don't use extension cords permanently—install additional outlets
3. Don't store daily items in hard-to-reach places
4. Don't walk around in dim lighting to "save electricity"
5. Don't ignore small hazards thinking "I know they're there"

pages.title: Safer Stairs
pages.content:
Safer Stairs

Stairs are one of the most dangerous areas in your home. About 20% of falls happen on stairs, and these falls often cause serious injuries. Making stairs safer is a critical fall prevention priority.

Why Stairs Are So Dangerous

Risk factors:
- Require good balance and strength
- Demand visual accuracy (judging depth/height)
- Often poorly lit
- Involve momentum and speed
- Little room for error
- Hard surfaces below

Injury risk: Stair falls cause more severe injuries than falls on level surfaces.

Essential Stair Safety Features

1. Handrails (Most Important)

Requirements:
- Handrails on BOTH sides of stairs
- Extend beyond top and bottom steps
- 34-38 inches high
- Easy to grip (1.25-2 inch diameter)
- Secure and sturdy (support 250+ pounds)

Why both sides matter:
- Use strongest hand going down
- May need support if carrying something
- Provides backup if one side fails

Installation:
- Professional installation recommended
- Must attach to wall studs, not just drywall
- Cost: $100-300 per side (worth every penny)

2. Lighting

Bright, even lighting is essential:
- Light switches at TOP and BOTTOM of stairs
  - Never walk stairs in dark to reach switch
  - Three-way switches are critical
- Illuminate entire staircase evenly
- Avoid shadows that hide step edges
- Minimum 100-watt equivalent brightness

Best lighting options:
- Overhead fixtures with bright bulbs
- Wall sconces every few steps
- LED strip lighting along handrail
- Motion-sensor lights for nighttime

3. Step Visibility

Make step edges obvious:
- Contrast tape on each step edge
  - Bright yellow, white, or reflective tape
  - Available at hardware stores ($10-15)
- Ensure steps are same color as edges stand out
- Replace worn carpet that obscures edges

Depth perception:
- All steps should be identical height
- Uneven steps are extremely dangerous
- Mark any irregular step with extra-bright tape

Stair Surface Safety

Carpet

Secure installation:
- No loose or worn spots
- Padding shouldn't bunch or shift
- Edges securely fastened
- Replace if showing wear

Alternatives to full carpet:
- Carpet runner with slip-resistant backing
- Non-slip stair treads ($5-10 per step)
- Rubberized stair coating

Hard Surface Stairs

Slip prevention:
- Apply non-slip adhesive strips to each step
- Consider rubber stair treads
- Never wax or polish stairs
-Clean up spills immediately

Going Up and Down Safely

Basic Stair Safety Rules

Going DOWN (more dangerous):
1. Always use handrail
2. Take one step at a time
3. Look at each step
4. Go slowly—never rush
5. Avoid carrying large items that block view
6. Don't wear bifocals (distort vision on stairs)

Going UP:
1. Use handrail for support and balance
2. Take one step at a time
3. Rest if needed
4. Don't overexert yourself

What NOT to Do on Stairs

Never:
- Run on stairs
- Skip steps
- Walk in socks or slippery footwear
- Multitask (talk on phone, carry laundry)
- Go up/down when dizzy or lightheaded
- Wear long robes or pants that drag

Outdoor Steps and Stairs

Weather challenges:
- Ice and snow removal is critical
- Salt or sand icy steps immediately
- Install heated mats or cables
- Use ice-melting products
- Consider temporarily avoiding outdoor stairs in bad weather

Railings:
- Even 1-2 steps need a handrail
- Must be rust-proof and weather-resistant
- Check stability regularly

Visibility:
- Paint edges of outdoor steps
- Install motion-sensor lights
- Reflective tape for nighttime visibility

Basement Stairs (Especially Hazardous)

Common problems:
- Often steeper than other stairs
- Inadequate lighting
- No second handrail
- Cement or hard surfaces below
- Cluttered with stored items

Solutions:
- Excellent lighting (battery backup for power outages)
- Bright paint on step edges
- Keep completely clear of storage
- Consider avoiding basement if too risky
- Move laundry upstairs if possible

Alternatives to Stairs

If stairs become too risky:
- Move bedroom to first floor
- Install stair lift ($3,000-5,000)
- Add bathroom to first floor
- Consider single-level living
- Evaluate if home is still appropriate

Temporary solutions:
- Take stairs only when well-rested
- Go up/down less frequently
- Have someone assist
- Use alternative entrance if available

Stair Equipment

Helpful aids:
- Stair lifts: Motorized chair carries you up/down ($3,000-10,000)
- Vertical platform lifts: wheelchair-accessible ($10,000-15,000)
- Additional handrails: Can be added even if one exists
- Illuminated handrails: Built-in LED lighting
- Tread lights: Individual step illumination

Warning Signs You Should Avoid Stairs

Consult your doctor if you:
- Feel unsteady or dizzy on stairs  
- Need to rest multiple times
- Have fallen on stairs before
- Feel frightened of stairs
- Avoid stairs due to fear
- Have significant vision problems

Emergency Preparedness

If you live in multi-level home:
- Keep phone on each level
- Have escape plan that doesn't require stairs
- Consider medical alert system
- Inform

pages.title: Simple Equipment That Helps
pages.content:
Simple Equipment That Helps

Assistive devices and safety equipment can dramatically reduce fall risk. Many are inexpensive and don't require installation. Knowing what's available helps you choose the right tools for your needs.

Bathroom Equipment

Grab Bars
Most important safety device:
- Permanent installation ($15-40 per bar + installation)
- Suction-cup grab bars for renters ($20-35, less secure)
- Must support 250+ pounds

Raised Toilet Seats
Makes getting up easier:
- Adds 3-6 inches of height ($25-60)
- Portable (no installation)
- With or without armrests
- Some attach securely, others just sit on top

Toilet Safety Frames
Armrests for support:
- Freestanding around toilet ($40-100)
- Easy installation
- Adjustable height
- Folds for travel

Shower and Tub Equipment
- Shower chair: Sit while bathing ($30-150)
- Transfer bench: Straddles tub edge ($40-80)
- Hand-held shower head: Control water flow ($20-100)
- Non-slip mats: Adhesive strips or suction mats ($10-25)
- Bath lift: Mechanically lowers you into tub ($200-500)

Mobility Aids

Canes
When you need a cane:
- Mild balance problems
- One-sided weakness
- Need occasional support

Types:
- Standard single-point: Most common ($15-30)
- Quad cane: Four-footed base, more stable ($25-45)
- Offset handle: Ergonomic grip ($20-35)

Proper fit:
- Handle at wrist height when standing
- Elbow bent 15-20 degrees
- Use on opposite side of weakness
- Replace worn rubber tip

Walkers
When you need a walker:
- Moderate to severe balance problems
- Need support on both sides
- Recovering from surgery/injury

Types:
- Standard walker: Pick up and move ($30-60)
- Front-wheeled walker: Two front wheels ($40-70)
- Four-wheeled rollator: All wheels, has seat and brakes ($60-150)
- Knee walker: For foot/ankle injuries ($100-200)

Choosing:
- Rollators best for outdoor use
- Standard walkers most stable
- Must have hand brakes that work well
- Seat useful for resting

Proper fit:
- Handles at wrist height
- Arms bent 15-20 degrees
- Should stand upright, not lean forward

Wheelchairs
When mobility is very limited:
- Can't walk safely even with walker
- Severe balance or strength problems
- Long distances only

Types:
- Manual: Self-propel or pushed ($100-500)
- Transport chair: Lightweight, must be pushed ($100-200)
- Power: Battery-operated ($1,000-5,000+)

Home Safety Equipment

Lighting
- Motion-sensor nightlights: Auto on/off ($8-15 each)
- Touch lamps: Easy to turn on ($15-30)
- Smart bulbs: Voice or phone control ($10-20/bulb)
- Emergency light: Turns on when power fails ($15-25)

Reaching and Grabbing

- Reacher/grabber: Pick up items without bending ($10-25)
- Sock aid: Put on socks independently ($5-15)
- Long-handled shoehorn: Don't bend to put on shoes ($10-20)
- Dressing stick: Help with clothes ($10-15)

Step Stools and Ladders
If you must use them:
- Step stool with handrail ($40-80)
- Non-slip surface
- Wide base
- Better option: Store items at accessible height

Bed Safety
- Bed rails: Assist getting in/out ($30-80)
- Bed cane/pole: Leverage for standing ($40-70)
- Bed risers: Raise bed height ($15-30)

Floor Safety
- Non-slip rug pads: If you must keep rugs ($10-20)
- Contrast tape: Mark step edges ($10-15)
- Corner guards: Protect from sharp edges ($5-10)

Footwear

Indoor
- Non-slip slippers: Rubber soles, secure fit ($15-40)
- Diabetic shoes: Extra support and cushioning ($50-100)
- Walking shoes: Athletic shoes indoors ($40-100)

Avoid:
- Socks alone
- Backless slippers
- Smooth-soled shoes
- Thongs/flip-flops

Outdoor
- Walking shoes: Good tread, ankle support ($50-150)
- Winter boots: Non-slip sole, waterproof ($60-120)
- Ice cleats: Attach to shoes for ice ($15-30)

Medical Alert Systems

If living alone:
- Basic system: Button to call for help ($25-45/month)
- Fall detection: Auto-calls if fall detected ($30-50/month)
- GPS-enabled: Works away from home ($35-55/month)
- Two-way voice: Speak to operator through device

How they work:
- Wear pendant or wristband
- Press button in emergency
- Connects to monitoring center
- They call family or 911

Worth it if you:
- Live alone
- Have high fall risk
- Worry about not being found
- Have fallen before

Exercise Equipment

Balance Training
- Balance board: Improve stability ($20-40)
- Balance pad: Foam surface ($15-30)
- Exercise ball: Core strength ($15-25)

Strength Training
- Resistance bands: Portable, adjustable ($10-25)
- Light weights: 1-5 lb dumbbells ($10-40)
- Ankle weights: Progressive resistance ($15-30)

Flexibility
- Yoga mat: Safe floor surface ($15-30)
- Stretching strap: Assistance with stretches ($8-15)

Technology Aids

Vision
- Magnifying glasses: See small items ($10-30)
- Bright LED flashlights: Always handy ($10-25)
- Large-button phones: Easier to dial ($30-50)

Memory and Organization
- Pill organizers: Daily/weekly doses ($5-15)
- Medication reminder alarms: Alerts when to take ($10-30)
- Calendar clocks: Shows day/date clearly ($30-50)

How to Choose Equipment

pages.title: When to Ask for a Review
pages.content:
When to Ask for a Review

Regular comprehensive fall risk assessments help catch problems early. Know when to request evaluation from your healthcare team.

Annual Fall Risk Assessment

Everyone over 65 should have yearly assessment:
- Fall history
- Gait and balance testing
- Medication review
- Vision check
- Home safety discussion

Ask your doctor:
"Can we do a fall risk assessment at my next visit?"

Request Immediate Assessment If:

You've Fallen
After any fall:
- Even if not injured
- Even if you "know why" it happened
- Comprehensive evaluation needed

Near-Falls or Balance Changes
- Frequent close calls
- Feeling increasingly unsteady
- New balance problems
- Fear of falling limiting activities

Medication Changes
Request review after:
- Starting new medication
- Dose changes
- New dizziness or drowsiness
- Taking 4+ medications

Vision Changes
- Difficulty seeing clearly
- New glasses needed
- After cataract surgery
- Progressive vision loss

New Medical Diagnosis
Conditions affecting fall risk:
- Parkinson's disease
- Stroke
- Diabetes
- Heart rhythm problems
- Arthritis worsening

After Hospitalization
Always request assessment:
- Deconditioning from bed rest
- New medications
- May need physical therapy
- Home safety needs may have changed

What a Comprehensive Assessment Includes

Medical history:
- Fall and near-fall history
- Medications
- Chronic conditions
- Previous injuries

Physical examination:
- Gait observation
- Balance tests (one-leg stand, TUG test)
- Vision screening
- Footwear check
- Blood pressure (sitting and standing)
- Strength testing

Functional assessment:
- Ability to perform daily tasks
- Use of assistive devices
- Home safety concerns

Recommendations:
- Exercise prescription
- Physical therapy referral
- Home modifications
- Medication adjustments
- Vision/hearing evaluation
- Assistive devices

Specialists Who Can Help

Physical Therapist:
- Gait and balance evaluation
- Exercise program
- Assistive device training
- Fall recovery if you've fallen

Occupational Therapist:
- Home safety assessment
- Adaptive equipment recommendations
- Daily task modifications

Pharmacist:
- Medication therapy management
- Interaction checks
- Safer alternatives

Ophthalmologist/Optometrist:
- Comprehensive vision exam
- Cataract evaluation
- Prescription update

Podiatrist:
- Foot examination
- Neuropathy assessment
- Footwear recommendations
- Custom orthotics

Medicare Coverage

Medicare covers:
- Annual wellness visit (includes fall risk screening)
- Some physical therapy
- Durable medical equipment
- Vision exams for certain conditions

Ask about:
- SilverSneakers or fitness programs
- Home health services if homebound
- Diabetic shoe program

Preparing for Your Appointment

Bring:
- List of all medications (or the bottles)
- List of previous falls and near-falls
- Questions about specific concerns
- Family member if helpful

Be ready to discuss:
- When and where falls occurred
- What you were doing
- Any injuries
- Changes in function
- Fear of falling

Red Flags Requiring Immediate Evaluation

Don't wait—seek care now if:
- Multiple falls in short period
- Falls with loss of consciousness
- Falls causing injuries
- Sudden balance changes
- Unexplained weakness
- Severe dizziness

Follow-Up Schedule

How often to reassess:
- No falls, low risk: Annually
- After fall: Within 2-4 weeks
- High risk: Every 3-6 months
- After interventions: 6-12 weeks to assess progress

Tracking Your Progress

Monitor improvements:
- Balance test results
- Number of near-falls
- Confidence in activities
- Daily function
- Exercise tolerance

Keep records:
- Falls and near-falls
- Medication changes
- Test results
- Recommendations made

Being Your Own Advocate

Speak up if:
- Doctor dismisses falls as "normal aging"
- You feel unsafe but told you're fine
- Recommendations unclear
- Not improving with interventions

Good phrases:
"I'm concerned about my fall risk and would like a comprehensive assessment."
"What specific steps can I take to reduce my risk?"
"Can you refer me to physical therapy?"
"I'd like my medications reviewed for fall risk."

Remember

Fall risk assessment isn't a one-time event—it's an ongoing process. Your risk changes with new conditions, medications, and life circumstances.

Don't wait for a fall to request evaluation. Proactive assessment can prevent falls before they happen.

You know your body best. If something feels "off," trust that instinct and request assessment.

Fall prevention is a team effort, but you're the team captain. Advocate for yourself and ask for the help you need.

pages.title: Dizziness and Blood Pressure
pages.content:
Dizziness and Blood Pressure

Dizziness and blood pressure problems are common fall causes. Understanding and managing them can significantly reduce your risk.

Types of Dizziness

Lightheadedness
- Feels like: Might faint, woozy
- Common causes: Low blood pressure, dehydration, medications
- Fall risk: High when sudden

Vertigo
- Feels like: Room spinning
- Common causes: Inner ear problems (BPPV, Meniere's)
- Fall risk: Very high during episodes

Disequilibrium
- Feels like: Unsteady, off-balance
- Common causes: Multiple system problems
- Fall risk: Persistent risk

Orthostatic Hypotension (Postural Blood Pressure Drop)

What happens:
- Blood pressure drops when standing
- Brain briefly gets less blood
- Causes dizziness, lightheadedness
- Vision may dim

Numbers:
- Drop of 20+ points systolic OR
- Drop of 10+ points diastolic
- Within 3 minutes of standing

Causes:
- Dehydration
- Blood pressure medications
- Prolonged bed rest
- Parkinson's disease
- Diabetes

Prevention Strategies

Stand up slowly:
1. Sit on edge of bed/chair for 30 seconds
2. Then stand slowly
3. Hold onto something
4. Wait before walking

Hydration:
- Drink 6-8 glasses water daily
- More in hot weather
- Avoid excessive caffeine/alcohol

Compression stockings:
- Help blood return from legs
- Especially helpful in morning
- Get proper fit

Medication timing:
- Don't take blood pressure meds at bedtime
- Discuss timing with doctor
- May need dose adjustment

Other strategies:
- Sleep with head slightly elevated
- Flex ankles before standing
- Eat small, frequent meals
- Avoid hot showers

Blood Pressure Management

Too Low
Symptoms:
- Dizziness when standing
- Fatigue
- Blurry vision
- Weakness

Causes:
- Medications (most common)
- Dehydration
- Heart problems
- Endocrine disorders

Too High
Why it matters for falls:
- Medications to treat it can cause low BP
- May affect blood flow to brain
- Increases stroke risk

Target: Generally 130/80 or less, but individualized for older adults

Medication-Related Dizziness

High-risk medications:
- Blood pressure medications (especially multiple)
- Diuretics
- Sedatives/sleep aids
- Antidepressants

What to do:
- Report dizziness immediately
- Don't stop medications on your own
- Doctor may adjust dose or timing
- Sometimes switching medications helps

When Dizziness Is Dangerous

Call 911 if dizziness with:
- Chest pain
- Severe headache
- Weakness on one side
- Slurred speech
- Difficulty walking
- Loss of consciousness

See doctor soon if:
- New or worsening dizziness
- Frequent episodes
- Affects daily activities
- After medication change

BPPV (Benign Positional Vertigo)

Most common cause of vertigo

Symptoms:
- Brief spinning with position changes
- Rolling over in bed
- Looking up
- Bending over

Treatment:
- Epley maneuver (simple procedure)
- Very effective
- Physical therapy
- Often resolves in weeks

Testing and Evaluation

Your doctor may:
- Check blood pressure lying and standing
- Review medications
- Blood tests (anemia, thyroid)
- Heart rhythm check
- Balance testing
- Vestibular testing if indicated

Self-Monitoring

Keep a diary:
- When dizziness occurs
- What you were doing
- How long it lasted
- Associated symptoms
- Recent meals/medications

Check your blood pressure:
- Home monitor ($30-60)
- Sitting and standing
- Same time each day
- Bring log to appointments

Diet and Hydration

Helpful strategies:
- Adequate salt (unless restricted)
- Small, frequent meals
- Avoid alcohol
- Limit caffeine
- Stay hydrated

Avoid:
- Skipping meals
- Standing long periods
- Hot baths/showers
- Large, carbohydrate-heavy meals

Remember

Dizziness is never normal and always warrants evaluation. Most causes are treatable.

Simple position changes done slowly can prevent many dizzy-related falls.

If you're dizzy, don't try to "push through it"—sit or lie down immediately and call for help if needed.

Work with your doctor to find the right balance with blood pressure medications—too low is as dangerous as too high.

pages.title: Foot Care and Footwear
pages.content:
Foot Care and Footwear

Your feet are your foundation. Proper foot care and appropriate footwear are essential for balance and fall prevention.

Why Feet Matter

Your feet:
- Provide your base of support
- Contain sensors that detect ground texture
- Must be strong and flexible for balance
- Absorb shock when walking

Problems affect: Balance, gait, pain, and fall risk.

Common Foot Problems

Peripheral Neuropathy
What it is: Nerve damage causing numbness

Causes:
- Diabetes (most common)
- Vitamin B12 deficiency
- Alcohol use
- Chemotherapy

Why it's dangerous:
- Can't feel ground
- Don't notice blisters/injuries
- Impaired balance
- Increased fall risk 2-3 times

Management:
- Control blood sugar (if diabetic)
- B12 supplementation if deficient
- Daily foot inspections
- Protective footwear

Bunions and Hammertoes
Problems:
- Painful deformities
- Affect shoe fit
- Alter gait
- Reduce balance

Treatment:
- Proper footwear
- Padding
- Orthotics
- Surgery if severe

Plantar Fasciitis
Symptoms:
- Heel pain, especially morning
- Affects walking
- Causes limping

Treatment:
- Stretching exercises
- Supportive shoes
- Orthotics
- Ice

Arthritis in Feet
Impact:
- Stiffness and pain
- Reduced flexibility
- Altered gait
- Balance problems

Management:
- Anti-inflammatory medications
- Exercise
- Proper footwear
- Assistive devices

Calluses and Corns
Why they matter:
- Painful
- Change how you walk
- Can hide serious problems

Prevention:
- Proper-fitting shoes
- Regular foot care
- Moisturize skin

Foot Care Basics

Daily Inspection
Check for:
- Cuts or sores
- Blisters
- Redness or warmth
- Swelling
- Color changes

Especially if you have:
- Diabetes
- Peripheral neuropathy
- Poor circulation
- Vision problems

Use mirror if can't see bottom of feet.

Toenail Care
Proper trimming:
- Cut straight across
- Not too short
- File sharp edges
- Never cut into corners

Thick nails:
- See podiatrist
- Special tools needed
- Risk of injury if you trim

Skin Care
Keep skin healthy:
- Moisturize daily (not between toes)
- Dry thoroughly after bathing
- Check for fungal infections
- Treat athlete's foot promptly

When to See a Podiatrist

Regular visits if you have:
- Diabetes
- Peripheral neuropathy
- Circulation problems
- Difficulty trimming nails
- Persistent foot pain

Seek immediate care for:
- Non-healing wounds  
- Signs of infection
- Sudden pain or swelling
- Color changes

Footwear Essentials

Proper Shoe Fit

Characteristics of good shoes:
- Fits snugly but not tight
- Room for toes (thumb width at end)
- Secure heel (doesn't slip)
- Supports arch
- Cushioned sole
- Non-slip bottom

When to shop:
- Late afternoon (feet swell during day)
- Bring socks you'll wear
- Try both shoes
- Walk around store

Shoe Features for Fall Prevention

Must-haves:
- Flat or very low heel (if any heel, keep ≤1 inch)
- Wide, stable heel base (not narrow)
- Non-slip rubber sole  
- Secure fastening (laces, velcro, buckles)
- Good arch support
- Cushioned insole
- Lightweight

Best examples: Flat walking shoes, sneakers, athletic shoes

Avoid:
- High heels (2+ inches)
- Slip-on shoes without secure fit
- Smooth leather soles
- Platform shoes
- Backless shoes/slippers
- Worn-out shoes

Indoor Footwear

Best choices:
- Athletic shoes
- Supportive slippers with backs and rubber soles
- Walking shoes

Never:
- Socks alone
- Bare feet
- Backless slippers
- Smooth-soled slippers

Outdoor Footwear

Walking/athletic shoes:
- Good tread
- Ankle support
- Water-resistant
- Replace when worn

Winter boots:
- Non-slip soles
- Waterproof
- Good traction
- Easy to get on/off

Ice cleats:
- Attach to shoes
- Metal coils or spikes
- Dramatically improve traction
- $15-30, worth every penny

Special Footwear Situations

Diabetic Shoes
Features:
- Extra depth
- No internal seams
- Protective toe box
- Custom orthotics

Medicare may cover with prescription.

Orthotics
Custom inserts:
- Support arches
- Cushion feet
- Correct gait abnormalities
- Reduce pain

Getting orthotics:
- Podiatrist evaluation
- Custom molded
- Insurance may cover

Compression Socks
Benefits:
- Reduce swelling
- Improve circulation
- May help with balance

Important: Get proper fit, don't cut off circulation.

Shoe Replacement

Replace shoes when:
- Soles worn smooth
- Heels worn unevenly
- Upper material damaged
- Lost cushioning
- Over 6-12 months old (even if look fine)

Cost vs. safety:
- Good shoes: $50-150
- Hip fracture treatment: $40,000+
- Shoes are a bargain

Exercises for Foot Health

Toe Curls
- Place towel on floor
- Use toes to scrunch toward you
- Strengthens foot muscles

Ankle Circles
- Sit in chair
- Lift foot
- Circle ankle both directions
- Improves mobility

Toe Spreads
- Spread toes apart
- Hold 5 seconds
- Improves toe strength and flexibility

Calf Stretches
- Stand facing wall
- One leg back
- Keep heel down
- Lean forward
- Improves ankle flexibility

Daily Foot Care Routine

Morning:
- Visual inspection  
- Put on appropriate footwear

pages.title: Introduction
pages.content:
Introduction

Beyond exercise and home safety, managing your health, vision, and medications is critical for fall prevention. This section covers medical factors you can control.

Why Medical Management Matters

The connection:
- Health conditions increase fall risk
- Medications affect balance
- Vision changes make navigation harder
- Foot problems impact stability

Good news: Most of these factors are modifiable with proper care.

What This Section Covers

1. Medications that increase fall risk
2. Vision and hearing health
3. Foot care and proper footwear
4. Managing dizziness and blood pressure
5. When to request a comprehensive review

Working with Your Healthcare Team

Fall prevention requires partnership with your medical providers:
- Primary care physician
- Pharmacist
- Optometrist/ophthalmologist
- Podiatrist
- Physical therapist

Remember

You have more control over medical fall risk factors than you might think. Regular check-ups, honest communication, and proactive management can dramatically reduce your risk.

pages.title: Medicines That Increase Fall Risk
pages.content:
Medicines That Increase Fall Risk

This lesson builds on the earlier detailed medication lesson to reinforce key points about managing fall risk from medications.

Key Medication Categories

Review the comprehensive medication lesson in Section 2 "Understanding Risk" for detailed information on:
- Sedatives and sleep medications
- Blood pressure medications
- Antidepressants
- Opioid pain medications
- Anti-anxiety medications

Critical Actions

Annual medication review:
- Bring ALL medications (including OTC) to doctor appointments
- Ask specifically about fall risk
- Request safer alternatives
- Discuss dose reductions

Work with pharmacist:
- Free medication therapy management
- Identify drug interactions
- Suggest timing strategies

Monitor yourself:
- Note any new dizziness after medication changes
- Report balance problems promptly
- Keep updated medication list

Remember

Never stop medications without consulting your doctor. The goal is to use the safest options at the lowest effective doses through partnership with your healthcare team.

pages.title: Vision and Hearing
pages.content:
Vision and Hearing

Good vision and hearing are essential for balance and fall prevention. Regular check-ups and proper correction can significantly reduce fall risk.

Vision and Falls

Why vision matters:
- Sees obstacles and hazards
- Judges distances and depth
- Detects changes in surface
- Helps brain understand body position

Statistics: Vision problems double fall risk.

Common Vision Problems

Cataracts
- Cloudy lens
- Blurry vision
- Difficulty with glare
- Poor night vision
- Surgery reduces fall risk by 30%

Glaucoma
- Peripheral vision loss
- Can't see obstacles to side
- Often no symptoms until advanced
- Regular screening critical (annual eye exams)

Macular Degeneration
- Central vision loss
- Difficulty seeing details
- Poor depth perception
- Can't see step edges clearly

Diabetic Retinopathy
- From diabetes
- Vision changes
- Can lead to blindness
- Tight blood sugar control prevents

Vision Care

Annual eye exams essential for those over 60

Update prescriptions:
- Changes can be gradual (you adapt without realizing)
- Outdated glasses increase fall risk
- Check prescription annually

Bifocals and multifocals:
- Can distort vision on stairs
- Consider separate reading/distance glasses
- Single-vision distance glasses for walking outdoors

Lighting:
- Aging eyes need 2-3x more light
- Eliminate glare
- Use task lighting

After eye procedures:
- Be extra careful during adjustment period
- Use railings
- Avoid stairs if vision blurry

Hearing and Balance

The connection:
- Inner ear controls balance
- Hearing loss may indicate balance system problems
- Can't hear environmental cues
- May not hear someone warning about hazard

Hearing loss increases fall risk by 30-140% (depending on severity).

Common Causes
- Age-related hearing loss
- Ear infections
- Earwax buildup (simple fix!)
- Meniere's disease
- Inner ear disorders

Vestibular Disorders

Inner ear problems:
- BPPV (benign positional vertigo)
- Vestibular neuritis
- Labyrinth itis

Symptoms:
- Room spinning
- Severe dizziness
- Nausea
- Balance problems

Treatment:
- Vestibular rehabilitation therapy
- Epley maneuver for BPPV
- Medications
- Balance retraining

Hearing Aids

Benefits beyond hearing:
- May improve balance
- Better environmental awareness
- Reduces isolation
- Improves safety

Getting help:
- Audiologist evaluation
- Modern aids are discreet
- Insurance may cover (check benefits)
- Start with one ear if cost prohibitive

Regular Screenings

Vision:
- Age 60+: Annual comprehensive eye exam
- With diabetes: Annual dilated exam
- If vision changes: Immediate exam

Hearing:
- Baseline at age 50
- Every 3 years if normal
- Annually if problems noted

When to seek help immediately

Vision:
- Sudden vision loss
- Flashes of light
- New floaters
- Eye pain
- Double vision

Hearing/Balance:
- Sudden hearing loss
- Severe dizziness
- Room spinning
- Unsteady gait
- Falls

Remember

Regular vision and hearing care are simple, effective fall prevention strategies. Don't accept decline as "normal aging"—many problems are treatable.

Annual exams detect problems early when treatment is most effective.

pages.title: Introduction
pages.content:
Introduction

Physical strength and balance are your body's best defense against falls. This section focuses on exercises and activities that keep you steady and strong.

Why Exercise for Fall Prevention?

The evidence is clear:
- Exercise is the single most effective fall prevention strategy
- Research shows 23-34% reduction in fall rates (2019 Cochrane review)
- Benefits seen in as little as 6-8 weeks
- Works at any age or fitness level

What Makes Exercise Effective?

Builds Muscle Strength
- Stronger legs catch you when you stumble
- Stronger hips improve stability
- Core strength maintains upright posture

Improves Balance
- Trains your body's balance systems
- Increases confidence in movement
- Helps you recover from stumbles

Enhances Flexibility
- Greater range of motion
- Easier to avoid obstacles
- Reduces injury if you do fall

Boosts Bone Strength
- Weight-bearing exercise strengthens bones
- Reduces fracture risk if you fall
- Slows osteoporosis progression

Types of Fall-Prevention Exercise

Balance Training (Most Important)
- Standing on one leg
- Tai Chi
- Yoga
- Walking heel-to-toe

Strength Training
- Bodyweight exercises (squats, chair stands)
- Resistance bands
- Light weights
- Functional movements

Flexibility and Stretching
- Maintains range of motion
- Reduces stiffness
- Improves posture

Aerobic Exercise
- Walking
- Swimming
- Cycling
- Dancing

How Much Exercise Do You Need?

Minimum effective dose:
- Balance exercises: 3+ times per week, 20-30 minutes
- Strength training: 2-3 times per week
- Walking: Most days, 20-30 minutes

Important: Consistency matters more than intensity

What This Section Covers

1. Why specific types of exercise matter
2. Simple exercises you can do at home
3. Safe walking practices
4. Evidence-based exercise programs

Safety First

Before starting:
- Talk to your doctor if you have health concerns
- Start slowly and build gradually
- Use stable support when needed
- Stop if you feel pain, dizzy, or short of breath

The Best Part

You don't need:
- A gym membership
- Special equipment (though some items help)
- Perfect health
- To be young or athletic

You just need:
- Commitment to regular practice
- Willingness to start small
- Patience for gradual improvement

Remember

Falls aren't caused by aging—they're caused by weakness and poor balance. Both are modifiable through exercise at any age.

The exercises in this section are specifically chosen because they prevent falls. This isn't just "staying active"—it's targeted fall prevention training.

pages.title: Simple Home Exercises
pages.content:
Simple Home Exercises

You don't need a gym or special equipment to build the strength and balance that prevent falls. These simple exercises can be done at home with just a sturdy chair and counter for support.

Before You Start

Safety reminders:
- Clear space around you
- Wear non-slip shoes or bare feet
- Have stable support nearby
- Start with easier versions
- Stop if you feel pain, dizzy, or short of breath

How often:
- 20-30 minutes
- 3-4 times per week
- At least 48 hours between strength sessions

Warm-up first: 5 minutes of gentle movement (marching in place, arm circles)

Strength Exercises

1. Chair Stands (Most Important)

Why: Mimics standing from toilet, getting out of car

How to do it:
1. Sit in sturdy armless chair
2. Feet flat on floor, hip-width apart
3. Cross arms over chest
4. Lean slightly forward
5. Stand up without using hands
6. Slowly sit back down with control

Goal: 10-15 repetitions, 2-3 sets

Easier: Use arms to push off
Harder: Hold position halfway up for 3 seconds

2. Wall Push-Ups

Why: Upper body strength for catching yourself

How to do it:
1. Stand arm's length from wall
2. Place palms on wall at shoulder height
3. Lean forward, bending elbows
4. Push back to starting position

Goal: 10-15 repetitions, 2 sets

Easier: Stand closer to wall
Harder: Step further from wall

3. Calf Raises

Why: Ankle strength for balance and walking

How to do it:
1. Stand behind sturdy chair, holding for balance
2. Rise up on toes
3. Hold 2-3 seconds
4. Slowly lower

Goal: 10-15 repetitions, 2 sets

Easier: Hold chair with both hands
Harder: Do on one leg at a time

4. Marching in Place

Why: Hip strength, balance, coordination

How to do it:
1. Stand behind chair for support
2. Lift one knee as high as comfortable
3. Lower slowly
4. Repeat with other leg

Goal: 20 steps (10 each leg), 2 sets

Easier: Lift knee lower, hold chair
Harder: Don't hold chair, lift knees higher

5. Sit-to-Stand (Modified)

Why: Functional strength for daily activities

How to do it:
1. Sit at front edge of chair
2. Lean forward with chest over knees
3. Stand up
4. Pause
5. Sit down slowly (most important part)

Goal: 10 repetitions, 2-3 sets

6. Side Leg Raises

Why: Hip strength for side-to-side stability

How to do it:
1. Stand behind chair
2. Lift one leg out to side
3. Keep toes pointing forward
4. Lower slowly
5. Repeat same leg for all reps, then switch

Goal: 10-15 each leg, 2 sets

Keep: Leg straight, standing leg slightly bent

7. Back Leg Raises

Why: Glute and low back strength

How to do it:
1. Stand behind chair
2. Lift one leg straight back
3. Don't lean forward
4. Squeeze buttocks
5. Lower slowly

Goal: 10-15 each leg, 2 sets

Balance Exercises

8. One-Leg Stand

Why: Directly improves static balance

How to do it:
1. Stand near counter
2. Lift one foot off ground (just an inch is fine)
3. Hold as long as possible
4. Use counter for balance if needed

Goal: Hold 10+ seconds each leg

Progress: Hold longer, lift knee higher, less support

9. Heel-to-Toe Walk

Why: Dynamic balance, like walking on a beam

How to do it:
1. Walk down hallway
2. Place heel of front foot directly against toes of back foot
3. Walk 10-20 steps

Keep: Counter or wall nearby for support

Goal: 20 steps without touching wall

10. Standing Knee Bends

Why: Balance while moving

How to do it:
1. Stand behind chair
2. Bend one knee, bringing foot toward buttocks
3. Hold 2-3 seconds
4. Lower slowly
5. Repeat

Goal: 10 each leg

11. Toe Stands

Why: Ankle and balance

How to do it:
1. Stand behind chair
2. Rise up on tip-toes
3. Hold 3-5 seconds
4. Lower slowly

Goal: 10 repetitions

Progress: Use less hand support

12. Back Leg Swing

Why: Dynamic balance, hip flexibility

How to do it:
1. Stand behind chair
2. Swing one leg back and forth
3. Keep standing leg slightly bent
4. Smooth, controlled movement

Goal: 10 swings each leg

Flexibility Exercises

13. Ankle Circles

Why: Ankle mobility

How to do it:
1. Sit in chair
2. Lift one foot off ground
3. Circle ankle clockwise 10 times
4. Then counterclockwise 10 times
5. Repeat other ankle

14. Seated Hip Stretch

Why: Hip flexibility

How to do it:
1. Sit in chair
2. Cross one ankle over opposite knee
3. Gently lean forward
4. Hold 15-30 seconds

Goal: Repeat 2-3 times each side

15. Hamstring Stretch

Why: Leg flexibility, reduces fall risk

How to do it:
1. Sit at edge of chair
2. Extend one leg straight, heel on floor
3. Lean forward from hips
4. Hold 15-30 seconds

Avoid: Rounding back

Sample 30-Minute Routine

Warm-up (5 minutes):
- March in place: 1 minute
- Arm circles: 1 minute
- Ankle circles: 1 minute
- Gentle stretching: 2 minutes

Strength (15 minutes):
- Chair stands: 2 sets of 10
- Wall push-ups: 2 sets of 10
- Side leg raises: 2 sets of 10 each leg
- Back leg raises: 2 sets of 10 each leg
- Calf raises: 2 sets of 15

Balance (8 minutes):
- One-leg stand: Hold 10 seconds each leg, repeat 3 times
- Heel-to-toe walk: 20 steps, repeat 3 times

pages.title: Walking Safely
pages.content:
Walking Safely

Walking is one of the best exercises for fall prevention—but only if done safety. This lesson covers how to walk confidently and avoid common hazards.

Benefits of Walking

For fall prevention:
- Builds leg strength
- Improves balance and coordination
- Maintains bone density
- Enhances cardiovascular fitness
- Boosts mood and confidence

Research shows: Regular walking reduces fall risk by 20-30%

Proper Walking Technique

Posture

- Head up: Look ahead, not down at feet
- Shoulders back: Avoid hunching forward
- Chest out: Open posture
- Core engaged: Slight abdominal tightening
- Arms swing: Naturally at sides

Gait
- Heel-to-toe: Land on heel, roll through to toes
- Normal stride: Don't take tiny shuffling steps
- Smooth movement: Avoid jerky or stiff walking
- Even pace: Consistent speed

Common Walking Mistakes
-Looking down constantly (affects balance)
- Shuffling feet (trip hazard)
- Leaning too far forward
- Taking steps that are too long or too short
- Walking too slowly (actually less stable)

Indoor Walking Safety

At Home
- Clear all walking paths
- Remove throw rugs
- Ensure good lighting
- Don't carry large items that block vision
- Wear proper footwear (not socks alone)
- Don't rush to answer phone or door

Shopping/Public Buildings
- Use shopping cart for support if needed
- Avoid crowds when possible
- Watch for wet floors
- Take your time on escalators/moving walkways
- Rest when tired

Outdoor Walking Safety

Choosing Routes
- Start with familiar, flat areas
- Avoid uneven sidewalks initially
- Stay in well-lit areas
- Walking during daylight hours
- Routes with benches for resting

Weather Considerations

Rain:
- Wet surfaces extremely slippery
- Reduced visibility
- Consider indoor walking instead
- If must go out, slow down significantly

Ice and Snow:
- Most dangerous conditions
- Ice cleats on shoes ($15-30)
- Walk like a penguin (small steps, arms out)
- Best option: Indoor walking until clear

Hot Weather:
- Stay hydrated
- Walk during cooler parts of day
- Watch for dizziness/fatigue
- Can affect blood pressure medications

Surface Awareness
- Concrete: Generally safe, watch for cracks
- Asphalt: Can be uneven, affected by weather
- Grass: Uneven, hides obstacles
- Gravel: Unstable, difficult balance
- Sand: Very challenging balance

Walking aids

When to Use
- Feel unsteady
- Have balance problems
- Recovering from injury
- Long distances
- Unfamiliar terrain

Types

Cane:
- Mild balance issues
- Use on opposite side of weakness
- Proper height critical

Walker:
- Moderate to severe balance problems
- More stable than cane
- Rollator best for outdoor use

Using Aids Correctly:
- Professional fitting essential
- Learn proper technique
- Check rubber tips regularly
- Don't be embarrassed—they enable independence

Walking Speed

Too slow = less stable:
- Need certain speed for balance
- Momentum helps
- Don't creep along

Too fast = dangerous:
- Can't react to hazards
- More forceful fall if you trip

Just right = comfortable pace:
-Normal conversation possible
- Not rushed
- Steady, even steps

Dual-Task Walking

The problem:
- Walking while doing other tasks is harder
- Talking, carrying, looking around
- Increases fall risk significantly

Safer approach:
- Stop walking to have conversation
- Put packages down to open doors
- Stand still to look at phone
- Single-task when on stairs or uneven ground

Footwear for Walking

Best choices:
- Athletic/walking shoes
- Low, wide heel
- Non-slip rubber sole
- Laces or velcro (secure fit)
- Good arch support

Avoid:
- High heels
- Backless shoes/slippers
- Smooth leather soles
- Shoes that are too big
- Flip-flops
- Platform shoes

Building a Walking Program

Week 1-2:
- 10 minutes daily
- Flat, familiar routes
- Indoor or safe outdoor

Week 3-4:
- 15-20 minutes
- Begin slight variation in route
- Practice turning, stopping

Week 5+:
- Work toward 30 minutes
- More challenging routes
- Different surfaces (safely)

Sample Walking Routine
- 5 min warm-up (slow pace)
- 20 min moderate pace
- 5 min cool-down (slow pace)
- Light stretching after

Walking Indoors

Home:
- Up and down hallways
- Around rooms in circuit
- Stairs (if safe)

Shopping malls:
- Climate controlled
- Flat, smooth surface
- Other walkers
- Benches available
- Open before stores (mall walking groups)

Community centers:
- Indoor tracks
- Walking groups
- Supervised
- Social aspect

Walking with Others

Benefits:
- Motivation and accountability
- Safety (someone nearby if you fall)
- Social interaction
- More enjoyable

Group walking:
- Senior center programs
- Neighborhood groups
- Mall walking clubs
- YMCA programs

Monitoring Intensity

Talk test:
- Should be able to talk but slightly breathless
- If can't talk, too hard
- If can sing, too easy

Perceived exertion:
- Moderate: noticeable effort but not exhausting
- Can continue 20-30 minutes
- Feel worked but not wiped out

Obstacles and Hazards

Common outdoor hazards:
- Curbs (use curb cuts, watch hei

pages.title: Why Balance Matters
pages.content:
Why Balance Matters

Good balance keeps you upright and steady. When balance falters, falls happen. Understanding and improving your balance is essential for fall prevention.

What Is Balance?

Balance is your body's ability to maintain stability while standing or moving. It requires coordination between multiple systems:

Three Balance Systems

1. Vision (Eyes)
- Sees your surroundings
- Judges distances and obstacles
- Detects movement and position

2. Vestibular (Inner Ear)
- Detects head movement and position
- Senses acceleration and rotation  
- Provides spatial orientation

3. Proprioception (Body Awareness)
- Sensors in muscles, joints, and ligaments
- Feel where body parts are in space
- Detect surface texture under feet

These systems constantly communicate with your brain to maintain balance.

How Balance Decline Leads to Falls

Age-Related Changes

What happens:
- Inner ear function declines (starts age 40)
- Vision weakens (especially depth perception)
- Foot sensation decreases (peripheral neuropathy)
- Reaction time slows
- Muscle reflexes weaken

Result: Takes longer to detect and correct imbalance

The Balance-Fall Connection

Poor balance causes:
- Unsteadiness while standing still
- Difficulty walking on uneven surfaces
- Trouble recovering from stumbles
- Fear of movement
- Reduced confidence

Statistics:
- Poor balance increases fall risk 3-5 times
- Balance problems predict 76% of falls
- Can detect fall risk before first fall happens

Types of Balance

Static Balance
- Standing still without swaying
- Holding one position
- Required for: dressing, reaching overhead, standing in line

Dynamic Balance
- Maintaining stability while moving
- Adjusting to changing surfaces
- Required for walking, turning, stairs, avoiding obstacles

Reactive Balance
- Catching yourself when you stumble
- Quick adjustments to unexpected disruptions
- Critical for preventing falls

All three types can be improved with practice.

Warning Signs of Balance Problems

You may have balance issues if you:
- Feel unsteady standing or walking
- Hold onto walls, furniture, or people
- Feel like you might fall
- Avoid walking on uneven ground
- Have difficulty with stairs
- Turn your whole body instead of just your head
- Feel worse in the dark or with eyes closed
- Have fallen or nearly fallen recently

Conditions That Affect Balance

Vestibular Disorders
- BPPV (benign positional vertigo): Room-spinning sensation
- Meniere's disease: Vertigo, hearing loss, ringing
- Vestibular neuritis: Inner ear inflammation
- Labyrinthitis: Inner ear infection

Neurological Conditions
- Parkinson's disease
- Stroke
- Multiple sclerosis
- Peripheral neuropathy

Other Causes
- Vision problems
- Medications (especially multiple)
- Arthritis limiting joint movement
- Muscle weakness
- Low blood pressure

Balance vs. Dizziness

Balance problems:
- Feel unsteady or wobbly
- May not involve spinning sensation
- Worse with movement or position change
- Persistent or intermittent

Dizziness:
- Lightheaded or faint feeling
- Room spinning (vertigo)
- Often comes in episodes
- May indicate other health issues

Both increase fall risk and need evaluation.

Testing Your Balance

Self-Tests (from earlier lesson)
- One-leg stand test
- Tandem stand (heel-to-toe)
- Timed up and go
- Walking while turning head

Professional Assessment
- Romberg test (standing eyes closed)
- Dynamic gait index
- Berg balance scale
- Functional reach test
- Vestibular testing if indicated

Why Balance Training Works

Neuroplasticity:
- Brain can form new connections at any age
- Practice improves balance system coordination
- Benefits seen in 6-12 weeks

Muscle memory:
- Repeated movements become automatic
- Faster reactions to imbalance
- More efficient corrections

Confidence:
- Reduced fear of falling
- Increased activity
- Better overall function

Research shows: Balance training reduces falls by approximately 20-35% (systematic reviews)

Components of Balance Training

Challenge Your Base of Support
- Standing with feet together
- Standing on one leg
- Tandem stance (heel-to-toe)
- Standing on foam or unstable surface

Reduce Visual Input
- Close eyes during balance exercises
- Practice in dim light (safely)
- Look side to side while standing

Dynamic Movements
- Weight shifts
- Reaching in different directions
- Walking on different surfaces
- Turning and pivoting

Dual-Task Training
- Balancing while doing cognitive task
- Walking while talking
- Balancing while carrying object

How to Improve Balance

Daily Activities That Help
- Standing on one leg while brushing teeth
- Walking heel-to-toe down hallway
- Standing from chair without hands
- Tai Chi or yoga
- Dancing

Exercise Programs
- Group balance classes
- Tai Chi (evidence-based)
- Yoga adapted for seniors
- Physical therapy
- Otago Exercise Program

Duration Needed
- Minimum: 2-3 sessions per week
- Session length: 20-30 minutes
- Time to benefit: 6-12 weeks
- Maintenance: Continue indefinitely
