pages.title: Why Strength Matters
pages.content:
Why Strength Matters

Strong muscles are your first line of defense against falls. When you start to lose balance, muscle strength is what catches you and prevents you from hitting the ground.

How Strength Prevents Falls

Quick Reflexes Require Strong Muscles
What happens when you stumble:
1. Brain detects you're falling
2. Sends signal to muscles to correct
3. Strong muscles respond quickly and powerfully
4. You recover your balance

With weak muscles:
- Slower response time
- Insufficient power to catch yourself
- Fall happens before you can recover

Leg Strength Is Critical

Why legs matter most:
- Support your entire body weight
- Maintain standing balance
- Allow you to recover from stumbles
- Enable safe stair use

Key muscle groups:
- Quadriceps (front of thigh): Standing from sitting, stairs
- Glutes (buttocks): Hip stability, standing balance
- Calves: Ankle stability, pushing off when walking
- Hip abductors: Side-to-side stability

What Happens With Muscle Loss

Sarcopenia (Age-Related Muscle Loss)

Natural decline:
- Begins around age 30
- Accelerates after age 60
- Can lose 3-5% muscle mass per decade
- After 60: up to 1-2% loss per year

Without intervention:
- By age 80, may have lost 30-40% of muscle mass
- Dramatically increases fall risk
- Reduces independence

Good news: Strength training can reverse this loss at any age.

The Muscle-Fall Connection

Statistics:
- Weak leg muscles: Up to 3x higher risk for recurrent falls (research shows OR 1.76 for any fall, 3.06 for recurrent falls)
- Poor grip strength: 2x higher fall risk (indicator of overall strength)
- Can't stand from chair without hands: 3x higher fall risk

Warning Signs of Weakness

You may have significant muscle weakness if you:
- Need to push off with arms to stand from chair
- Avoid stairs because they're too difficult
- Have trouble getting out of car
- Feel unsteady when carrying items
- Fatigue quickly during normal activities
- Notice legs "giving out" occasionally

Specific Strength Needs

Standing Balance
Requires:
- Hip and ankle muscles constantly making small adjustments
- Core strength to maintain upright posture
- Leg endurance to stand for extended periods

Walking
Requires:
- Hip flexors to lift leg
- Quadriceps to support knee
- Calves to push off
- Glutes for stability

Sit-to-Stand (Most Important Functional Movement)
Requires:
- Quadriceps strength
- Glute activation
- Core stability

Why it matters: This movement happens dozens of times daily. Inability predicts falls.

Upper Body Strength Matters Too

Helps with:
- Using handrails effectively
- Catching yourself on furniture
- Using assistive devices
- Pushing up if you do fall

Grip strength:
- Excellent indicator of overall strength
- Predicts fall risk
- Essential for walker or cane use

Benefits Beyond Fall Prevention

Regular strength training:
- Improves bone density
- Enhances metabolism
- Reduces arthritis pain
- Increases energy
- Improves sleep
- Boosts mood and confidence

How Much Strength Do You Need?

Functional benchmarks:
- Chair stand test: Stand/sit 5 times in  10 seconds
- Grip strength: Varies by size, but should feel firm

You have adequate strength if you can:
- Stand from standard-height chair without using hands
- Walk up 10 stairs without holding on (if balance permits)
- Carry 10 pounds comfortably
- Get up from floor independently

Building Strength at Any Age

Key principles:
1. Progressive overload: Gradually increase difficulty
2. Specificity: Train movements you use daily
3. Consistency: 2-3 times per week minimum
4. Recovery: Rest 48 hours between strength sessions

It's Never Too Late

Research shows:
- 80-year-olds can double strength in 3 months
- 90-year-olds show significant gains
- Benefits seen regardless of starting level
- Improvements happen at any age

Types of Strength Training

Bodyweight Exercises
- Chair stands
- Wall push-ups
- Calf raises
- Squats (holding counter)

Advantage: No equipment needed, functional movements

Resistance Bands
- Adjustable resistance
- Safe and portable
- Low cost ($10-20)
- Versatile

Advantage: Easy on joints, good for beginners

Free Weights
- Dumbbells 1-10 pounds
- Ankle weights
- Wrist weights

Advantage: Precise loading, builds bone density

Machines (Gym)
- Guided movement
- Very safe
- Adjustable weight

Advantage: Good for those with balance concerns

Starting a Strength Program

If you're new to exercise:
1. Week 1-2: Learn movements without weight
2. Week 3-4: Add light resistance
3. Week 5: Gradual increases as tolerated

How to progress:
- Add repetitions first (up to 15)
- Then add weight/resistance
- Then add sets (up to 3)
- Never sacrifice form for weight

Safety Considerations

Do:
- Breathe normally (don't hold breath)
- Move slowly and controlled
- Stop if sharp pain occurs
- Use support as needed
- Start light and progress gradually

Don't:
- Hold your breath (raises blood pressure)
- Use momentum or jerky movements  
- Exercise if dizzy or unwell
- Push thro

pages.title: How to Check Your Own Risk
pages.content:
How to Check Your Own Risk

You can assess many fall risk factors on your own. These simple self-tests help you understand your current risk level and decide when to seek professional help.

Before You Start

Safety first:
- Perform these tests with someone nearby
- Do them near a sturdy chair or counter for support
- Stop immediately if you feel unsafe
- Skip any test if you've recently fallen or feel very unsteady

These tests don't replace professional medical evaluation—they supplement it.

Balance Self-Tests

1. One-Leg Stand Test

What it tests: Balance and leg strength

How to do it:
1. Stand near a counter (don't hold on unless needed)
2. Lift one foot about 6 inches off the ground
3. Time how long you can hold this position
4. Repeat with other leg

Results:
-  10 seconds: Good balance for age

2. Tandem Stand Test

What it tests: Balance control

How to do it:
1. Stand with one foot directly in front of the other (heel touching toes)
2. Hold position for 10 seconds
3. Try with eyes open, then eyes closed (if able)

Results:
- Can't hold 10 seconds: Balance issues—discuss with doctor
- Can hold 10+ seconds, eyes open: Adequate balance
- Can hold with eyes closed: Excellent balance

3. Reaching Test

What it tests: Balance while moving

How to do it:
1. Stand with arm raised to shoulder height
2. Reach forward as far as possible without

 stepping
3. Measure distance reached (have someone help)

Results:
-  10 inches: Lower risk

Strength Self-Tests

4. Sit-to-Stand Test

What it tests: Leg strength needed for daily activities

How to do it:
1. Sit in an armless chair (seat height ~17 inches)
2. Cross arms over chest
3. Stand up completely, then sit back down
4. Repeat 5 times as quickly as possible
5. Time yourself

Results for ages 65-69:
-  16 seconds: Below average—consider strength training

5. Chair Stand Test (Alternative)

Simpler version:
- Can you stand from a chair without using your hands?
- Yes comfortably: Good strength
- Barely or can't do it: Muscle weakness—needs attention

Walking and Gait Self-Tests

6. Timed Up and Go (TUG)

What it tests: Overall mobility and fall risk

Setup needed:
- A chair with arms
- Mark a line 10 feet away
- Timer

How to do it:
1. Sit in the chair
2. On "go," stand up
3. Walk to the line (normal pace)
4. Turn around
5. Walk back and sit down
6. Time the entire sequence

Results:
-  12 seconds: High risk—see your doctor
- > 20 seconds: Very high risk—immediate professional evaluation needed

7. Walking Speed Test

What it tests: Functional mobility

How to do it:
1. Mark a 10-foot walking path
2. Walk at your normal pace
3. Time how long it takes

Results:
-  6 seconds ( 1 year since eye exam?

Any "yes" answers: Schedule eye examination

Environmental Risk Assessment

9. Home Safety Walk-Through

Go through each room and check:

Floors:
- □ Any throw rugs?
- □ Clutter or obstacles?
- □ Slippery surfaces?
- □ Worn carpet or uneven flooring?

Lighting:
- □ Can you turn on lights before entering rooms?
- □ Are hallways and stairs well-lit?
- □ Do you have nightlights?

Stairs:
- □ Do all stairs have handrails?
- □ Are step edges visible?
- □ Any loose carpeting?

Bathroom:
- □ Grab bars near toilet and tub?
- □ Non-slip mat in tub/shower?
- □ Can you get in/out of tub safely?

Medical Risk Factors Checklist

10. Personal Risk Factor Count

Count how many apply to you:
- □ Previous fall in past year
- □ Feel unsteady when walking
- □ Worry about falling
- □ Dizzy or lightheaded sometimes
- □ Numbness in feet
- □ Take 4+ medications
- □ Take medications for sleep, anxiety, or depression
- □ Have had medication changes recently
- □ Arthritis, Parkinson's, or stroke
- □ Limit activities due to fear of falling

Score:
- 0-2: Low risk—maintain current efforts
- 3-4: Moderate risk—implement prevention strategies
- 5+: High risk—discuss with doctor

When to Seek Professional Evaluation

Schedule appointment if:
- You failed any balance or strength test
- TUG test took > 12 seconds
- You have 3+ risk factors
- You've fallen in the past year
- You feel unsafe or unsteady

Seek immediate care if:
- You're having frequent near-falls
- You've fallen multiple times
- You feel extremely unsteady
- You experience sudden balance changes

Tracking Your Progress

Retest every 3 months to monitor:
- Improvement from exercises
- Decline needing intervention
- Effects of new medications or conditions

Keep a record:
- Date of test
- Results
- How you felt
- Any concerns

What the Results Mean

Understanding Your Risk Level

Low Risk (passed most tests):
- Continue current active lifestyle
- Maintain home safety
- Stay vigilant for changes

Moderate Risk (some test failures):
- Start balance and strength exercises
- Make home modifications
- Review medications with doctor
- Increase awareness

High Risk (failed multiple tests):
- See doctor for comprehensive evaluation
- Consider physical therapy
- Make immediate home safety changes
- May need assistive devices

Next Steps Based

pages.title: Common Risk Factors
pages.content:
Common Risk Factors

Certain characteristics and conditions increase your likelihood of falling. Recognizing these helps you take preventive action.

Physical Risk Factors

Muscle Weakness
Signs:
- Difficulty getting up from a chair without using your arms
- Needing to hold onto walls or furniture when walking
- Feeling your legs "give out"

Why it matters: Weak leg muscles can't catch you when you stumble. Reduced strength in hips, knees, and ankles directly increases fall risk.

Balance Problems
Signs:
- Feeling unsteady when standing still
- Difficulty walking in a straight line
- Needing to look down at your feet constantly
- Swaying or grabbing for support

Why it matters: Good balance requires coordination between your eyes, inner ear, muscles, and brain. Problems with any of these systems affect stability.

Gait Changes
Warning signs:
- Taking small, shuffling steps
- Walking slowly or hesitantly
- Difficulty turning or changing direction
- Asymmetric walking pattern

Sensory Risk Factors

Vision Problems
Common issues:
- Cataracts or glaucoma
- Poor depth perception
- Difficulty adjusting to light changes
- Uncorrected nearsightedness or farsightedness
- Bifocals (can distort distance perception on stairs)

Statistics: People with vision problems are approximately 2x more likely to fall than those with good vision (research shows 1.7-2x increased risk).

Hearing Loss
Why it affects falls: Your inner ear helps control balance. Hearing loss may indicate balance system problems and also reduces environmental awareness.

Foot Problems
- Numbness or tingling (peripheral neuropathy)
- Pain when walking
- Bunions or hammertoes
- Thick toenails or calluses
- Loss of sensation (can't feel the ground)

Previous Falls

Critical fact: If you've fallen once, your chance of falling again doubles.

Why this happens:
- Fear of falling reduces activity
- Reduced activity weakens muscles
- Weaker muscles increase fall risk
- The cycle continues

Chronic Conditions

Several health conditions increase risk:
- Arthritis (joint pain affects movement)
- Diabetes (can cause nerve damage and vision problems)
- Parkinson's disease (affects gait and balance)
- Stroke (may cause weakness or balance problems)
- Heart disease or irregular heartbeat
- Osteoporosis (doesn't cause falls but increases fracture risk)

Medications

Taking 4 or more medications significantly increases fall risk, regardless of type. High-risk medications include:
- Blood pressure medicines
- Sleep medications
- Anti-anxiety drugs
- Antidepressants
- Pain medications

Other Risk Factors

Urinary Urgency
- Rushing to the bathroom, especially at night
- Incontinence concerns
- Frequent nighttime urination

Footwear
- Wearing only socks or slippers
- Loose-fitting shoes
- High heels or shoes with slick soles

Fear of Falling
- Becomes a self-fulfilling prophecy
- Causes you to limit activities
- Leads to weakness and isolation

How Many Risk Factors Do You Have?

0-1 factors: Low risk (maintain current health)
2-3 factors: Moderate risk (implement prevention strategies)
4+ factors: High risk (consult healthcare provider for comprehensive assessment)

What You Can Do

- Be honest about which factors apply to you
- Discuss risk factors with your doctor
- Start with the most modifiable factors
- Don't let multiple risks overwhelm you—address them one at a time

Remember

Identifying risk factors isn't about blame or fear. It's about understanding where to focus your prevention efforts for maximum benefit.

pages.title: Home Hazards
pages.content:
Home Hazards

Most falls happen at home, in familiar surroundings. Identifying and fixing home hazards is one of the most effective fall prevention strategies.

Where Falls Happen

Statistics:
- 55% of falls occur inside the home
- 20% happen on stairs or steps
- Bathrooms and bedrooms are the highest-risk rooms

Common Indoor Hazards

Floors and Surfaces

Throw Rugs and Mats
- Problems: Edges curl up, rugs slide on smooth floors
- Falls happen when: Toes catch on edges or rugs slip
- Solution: Remove all throw rugs or secure with non-slip backing

Clutter
- Problems: Shoes, cords, newspapers, bags on floor
- Falls happen when: You don't see objects or trip over them
- Solution: Keep walking paths completely clear

Slippery Floors
- Problems: Recently waxed, wet, or polished surfaces
- Falls happen when: Feet slide, especially in socks
- Solution: Use non-skid floor wax, clean up spills immediately

Lighting Issues

Insufficient Light
- Problems: Shadows, dark hallways, can't see obstacles
- Falls happen when: Eyes don't adjust quickly to darkness
- Solution: Install bright lights, use nightlights

Poor Light Placement
- Problems: Light switches far from room entrances
- Falls happen when: Walking in dark to reach switch
- Solution: Install switches at room entrances, use motion sensors

Stairs and Steps

Missing Handrails
- Falls happen when: Loss of balance with nothing to grab
- Solution: Install sturdy handrails on both sides

Poor Stair Visibility
- Problems: Can't see step edges, worn carpet, poor lighting
- Falls happen when: Misjudging step height or depth
- Solution: Mark step edges with bright tape, improve lighting

Unsafe Stair Features
- Loose carpet or treads
- Uneven step heights
- Items stored on stairs
- Narrow steps

Furniture and Layout

Unstable Furniture
- Problems: Using wobbly chairs or tables for support
- Falls happen when: Furniture tips or rolls away
- Solution: Remove wheeled furniture from support paths

Low Furniture
- Problems: Coffee tables, footstools, pet beds
- Falls happen when: Bumping into low objects
- Solution: Rearrange or remove items from walking paths

Reaching and Bending
- Problems: Items stored too high or too low
- Falls happen when: Overreaching, using unstable step stools
- Solution: Store frequently used items at waist height

Room-by-Room Hazards

Kitchen
- Spills on floor (water, oil, food)
- Step stools without handrails
- Cabinets too high
- Cords from appliances creating trip hazards

Bathroom
- Wet, slippery floors and tub
- No grab bars near toilet or shower
- Bath mats without suction cups
- Reaching over high tub sides

Bedroom
- Low bed height (hard to get in/out)
- Clutter on floor (clothes, shoes)
- Light switch far from bed
- Bedside tables just out of reach

Living Room
- Low coffee tables
- Extension cords across walking paths
- Thick carpets or rugs with padding
- Remote controls and reading materials on floor

Outdoor Hazards

Walkways and Driveways
- Cracked or uneven pavement
- Wet leaves, ice, or snow
- Poor lighting
- Lack of handrails on outdoor steps

Yard
- Uneven ground
- Garden hoses left across paths
- Rocks or roots
- Steps without visible edges

Pets

While we love our animals, they can increase fall risk:
- Tripping over pets underfoot
- Leashes tangling around legs
- Rushing to feed or let them out
- Pet toys left on floor

Solution: Train pets, use gates to control access, establish routines

Quick Home Safety Check

Walk through your home and ask:
- □ Can I walk freely without dodging objects?
- □ Are all areas well-lit?
- □ Can I reach light switches easily?
- □ Are floors non-slip and clear?
- □ Do all stairs have handrails?
- □ Is my bathroom safe when wet?

Professional Home Assessment

Consider asking for an occupational therapy home safety evaluation if you:
- Have fallen at home
- Feel unsafe navigating your home
- Recently developed mobility problems
- Are returning home after hospitalization

What You Can Do

Today:
- Pick up clutter from floors
- Turn on more lights
- Remove one throw rug

This Week:
- Install nightlights
- Move commonly used items to accessible heights
- Secure or remove all throw rugs

This Month:
- Install grab bars
- Improve stair lighting
- Consider handrail installation

Remember

Your home should be your safest place. Small modifications can dramatically reduce fall risk without sacrificing comfort or style.

pages.title: Introduction
pages.content:
Introduction

Understanding your personal fall risk is the first step toward preventing falls. Everyone's risk is different, and identifying yours helps you focus on the most effective prevention strategies.

Why Assess Your Risk?

Falls rarely happen by chance. They occur when multiple risk factors combine at the same moment. The good news: many risk factors can be reduced or eliminated.

Categories of Fall Risk

Internal Factors (Your Body)
- Muscle strength and balance
- Vision and hearing
- Chronic health conditions
- Medications you take

External Factors (Your Environment)
- Home hazards (lighting, clutter, stairs)
- Footwear choices
- Weather and outdoor conditions

Behavioral Factors (Your Choices)
- Activity level and exercise
- Alcohol use
- Rushing or multitasking
- Using assistive devices properly

The Truth About Risk

Important: Having risk factors doesn't mean you will fall. It means you should take specific actions to protect yourself.

Modifiable vs. Non-Modifiable Risks

You CAN'T change:
- Your age
- Past falls or injuries
- Some chronic conditions

You CAN change:
- Your strength and balance
- Your home environment
- How you manage medications
- Your footwear and habits

What This Section Covers

The following lessons will help you:
1. Identify common risk factors
2. Recognize home hazards
3. Understand medical conditions that increase risk
4. Learn about medications that affect balance
5. Check your own risk level

Remember

Risk assessment isn't about fear—it's about empowerment. When you know your risks, you can take targeted action to stay safe and independent.

pages.title: Medical Conditions That Increase Risk
pages.content:
Medical Conditions That Increase Risk

Several health conditions affect your balance, strength, or awareness, increasing the likelihood of falls. Understanding these helps you work with your healthcare team.

Neurological Conditions

Parkinson's Disease
How it increases fall risk:
- Shuffling gait and slow movements
- Reduced arm swing when walking
- Difficulty initiating movement
- "Freezing" episodes
- Postural instability

Prevention strategies:
- Physical therapy focusing on gait
- Medications timed appropriately
- Clearing wide walking paths
- Using assistive devices correctly

Stroke
How it increases fall risk:
- Weakness on one side of body
- Balance and coordination problems
- Vision changes
- Difficulty judging distances
- Reduced awareness of affected side

Important: Fall risk is highest in the first 6 months after stroke.

Peripheral Neuropathy
How it increases fall risk:
- Numbness in feet ("can't feel the ground")
- Reduced ability to detect texture changes
- Pain or burning sensations
- Difficulty knowing foot position without looking

Common causes: Diabetes, vitamin B12 deficiency, chemotherapy, alcohol use

Cardiovascular Conditions

Postural Hypotension (Low Blood Pressure When Standing)
What happens:
- Blood pressure drops when you stand up
- Causes dizziness, lightheadedness
- Vision may briefly dim
- May feel like you'll faint

Risk factors:
- Dehydration
- Blood pressure medications
- Prolonged bed rest
- Hot weather

Prevention:
- Stand up slowly (sit for a moment first)
- Avoid sudden position changes
- Stay hydrated
- Review medications with doctor

Heart Arrhythmias
How they increase fall risk:
- Irregular heartbeat reduces blood flow to brain
- Can cause sudden dizziness
- May lead to fainting (syncope)
- Creates unpredictable symptoms

Heart Failure
How it increases fall risk:
- Fatigue and weakness
- Shortness of breath limits activity
- Fluid buildup affects balance
- Medications (diuretics) may cause dizziness

Musculoskeletal Conditions

Arthritis
How it increases fall risk:
- Joint pain limits movement
- Stiffness, especially in morning
- Reduced range of motion
- Unstable or "giving way" joints
- Difficulty with stairs

Most problematic: Arthritis in hips, knees, and ankles

Osteoporosis
Important note: Osteoporosis doesn't directly cause falls, but:
- Makes fractures more likely if you do fall
- Hip fractures are especially dangerous
- Fear of fracture may reduce activity
- Less activity leads to weaker muscles

Vision and Ear Conditions

Cataracts
How they increase fall risk:
- Blurry or cloudy vision
- Difficulty seeing in bright light
- Poor night vision
- Double vision
- Cannot judge distances accurately

Good news: Cataract surgery significantly reduces fall risk.

Glaucoma
How it increases fall risk:
- Peripheral vision loss ("tunnel vision")
- Can't see obstacles to the side
- Difficulty adapting to light changes
- May not notice hazards

Macular Degeneration
How it increases fall risk:
- Central vision loss
- Difficulty recognizing faces or reading
- Poor depth perception
- Can't see details like step edges

Vestibular Disorders (Inner Ear)
How they increase fall risk:
- Vertigo (room spinning sensation)
- Dizziness and unsteadiness
- Nausea making it hard to focus
- Difficulty walking in dark

Common conditions: BPPV (benign positional vertigo), Meniere's disease

Metabolic and Endocrine Conditions

Diabetes
How it increases fall risk:
- Peripheral neuropathy (foot numbness)
- Vision problems (retinopathy)
- Hypoglycemia (low blood sugar) causes weakness, confusion
- Poor circulation affects healing

Prevention: Tight blood sugar control reduces complications

Thyroid Disorders
Hyperthyroidism (too much thyroid):
- Muscle weakness
- Rapid heartbeat
- Tremor

Hypothyroidism (too little thyroid):
- Fatigue and slow movements
- Balance problems
- Muscle weakness

Cognitive and Mental Health Conditions

Dementia and Alzheimer's Disease
How they increase fall risk:
- Poor judgment about safety
- Difficulty recognizing hazards
- Vision-spatial problems
- Wandering or pacing
- Forgetting to use assistive devices

Depression
How it increases fall risk:
- Reduced energy and motivation
- Difficulty concentrating
- Medications (see separate lesson)
- Less physical activity
- May not care about safety

Anxiety
How it increases fall risk:
- Fear of falling becomes excessive
- Muscle tension affects balance
- Medications may cause drowsiness
- Avoiding activity leads to deconditioning

Respiratory Conditions

COPD (Chronic Obstructive Pulmonary Disease)
How it increases fall risk:
- Shortness of breath limits activity
- Reduced exercise tolerance
- Muscle wasting from inactivity
- Using  oxygen tubing creates trip hazard

Multiple Conditions

Critical fact: Having multiple chronic conditions dramatically increases fall risk because:
- Effects combine and compound
- More medications needed
- Overall frailty increases
- Each condition limits function differently

Working with Yo

pages.title: Medicines That Affect Balance
pages.content:
Medicines That Affect Balance

Medications are essential for managing health conditions, but some can increase fall risk. Understanding which medications affect balance helps you work with your doctor to find safer alternatives.

The Medication-Fall Connection

Key statistics:
- Taking 4 or more medications of any type doubles fall risk
- 47% of older adults take 5+ medications
- Some medications affect balance even at normal doses

Important: Never stop medications on your own. Always consult your healthcare provider.

High-Risk Medication Categories

1. Sedatives and Sleep Medications

Drug names (examples):
- Benzodiazepines: diazepam (Valium), lorazepam (Ativan), alprazolam (Xanax)
- Sleep aids: zolpidem (Ambien), eszopiclone (Lunesta)
- Older sedatives: diphenhydramine (Benadryl PM)

How they increase fall risk:
- Cause drowsiness and confusion
- Slow reaction time
- Affect balance and coordination
- Create "morning hangover" effect
- Increase risk of nighttime falls

Special concern: Effects last longer in older adults—a medication taken at bedtime may still affect you the next morning.

2. Blood Pressure Medications

Drug categories:
- Diuretics ("water pills"): furosemide (Lasix), hydrochlorothiazide
- Beta-blockers: metoprolol, atenolol
- ACE inhibitors: lisinopril, enalapril
- Calcium channel blockers: amlodipine, diltiazem

How they increase fall risk:
- Can drop blood pressure too much
- Cause dizziness when standing (postural hypotension)
- Diuretics increase nighttime bathroom trips
- May cause lightheadedness and weakness

What to watch for:
- Feeling dizzy when you stand up
- Vision briefly dims when standing
- Feeling weak or lightheaded

3. Antidepressants

Drug categories:
- SSRIs: sertraline (Zoloft), fluoxetine (Prozac), citalopram (Celexa)
- Tricyclics: amitriptyline, nortriptyline
- SNRIs: duloxetine (Cymbalta), venlafaxine (Effexor)

How they increase fall risk:
- Cause drowsiness or dizziness
- Affect blood pressure
- Create confusion or unsteadiness
- Interact with other medications

Note: Untreated depression also increases fall risk, so don't avoid treatment—work with your doctor for the safest option.

4. Opioid Pain Medications

Drug names:
- Hydrocodone, oxycodone, morphine, tramadol, codeine, fentanyl

How they increase fall risk:
- Severe drowsiness and confusion
- Slow reflexes dramatically
- Affect judgment
- Cause constipation (leading to straining)
- Build tolerance (need higher doses over time)

Highest risk: Combining opioids with benzodiazepines or alcohol

5. Anti-Anxiety Medications

Drug names:
- Buspirone (BuSpar)
- Benzodiazepines (see sedatives above)
- Hydroxyzine (Vistaril)

How they increase fall risk:
- Similar to sedatives
- Reduce alertness
- Impair coordination
- Effects worsen with other medications

6. Antihistamines

Drug names:
- Diphenhydramine (Benadryl)
- Hydroxyzine
- Chlorpheniramine
- Found in: cold medicines, sleep aids, allergy pills

How they increase fall risk:
- Strong sedative effects
- Dry mouth and blurred vision
- Confusion in older adults
- Often combined with other medications

Hidden sources: Check labels on over-the-counter products—many contain these.

7. Muscle Relaxants

Drug names:
- Cyclobenzaprine (Flexeril)
- Methocarbamol (Robaxin)
- Carisoprodol (Soma)

How they increase fall risk:
- Extreme drowsiness
- Dizziness and weakness
- Poor coordination
- Should be avoided in older adults when possible

8. Diabetes Medications

Drug names:
- Insulin
- Glyburide, glipizide (sulfonylureas)
- Others: metformin, pioglitazone

How they increase fall risk:
- Hypoglycemia (low blood sugar) causes:
  - Weakness and shakiness
  - Confusion
  - Sweating and dizziness
  - Can lead to fainting

Prevention: Monitor blood sugar carefully, eat regularly

9. Seizure Medications

Drug names:
- Phenytoin (Dilantin)
- Carbamazepine (Tegretol)
- Gabapentin (Neurontin)
- Pregabalin (Lyrica)

How they increase fall risk:
- Drowsiness and dizziness
- Affect coordination and balance
- Vision changes (double vision)
- Confusion at higher doses

Polypharmacy (Taking Multiple Medications)

The problem:
- Each additional medication increases fall risk
- Medications interact with each other
- Side effects multiply
- Harder to identify which drug causes problems

Taking 5+ medications: Risk increases exponentially, not just additively

Drug Interactions

Dangerous combinations:
- Sedatives + blood pressure medications
- Opioids + benzodiazepines
- Alcohol + any sedating medication
- Multiple drugs with same side effects

Over-the-Counter (OTC) Medications

Don't forget to count:
- Sleep aids
- Cold and allergy medicines
- Pain relievers
- Herbal supplements
- Vitamins

Many OTC products contain ingredients that increase fall risk

What You Can Do

Medication Review Checklist

Bring to every doctor appointment:
- □ All prescription medications
- □ Over-the-counter medications
- □ Vitamins and supplements
- □ Herbal products
- □ Eye drops and topical creams

pages.title: How to Get Up Safely
pages.content:
How to Get Up Safely

If you've fallen and aren't seriously injured, getting up the right way prevents further injury. Never rush—take your time.

First: Assess Yourself

Before moving, check:
- Are you hurt?
- Can you move all limbs?
- Any severe pain?
- Bleeding?
- Hit your head?
- Feeling dizzy or confused?

If YES to any: Don't try to get up. Call for help.

If NO: You may be able to get up safely using the technique below.

Rest First

-Don't rush
- Lie still for a minute
- Catch your breath
- Let your body settle
- Plan your movements

The Safe Get-Up Method

Step 1: Roll to Your Side

- Roll onto your side (choose the stronger side if one arm/leg is weaker)
- Bend your knees
- Rest if needed

Step 2: Get to Hands and Knees
- Push up with your arms to prop yourself up on elbow
- Pull yourself to hands and knees position
- Rest again—this is tiring

Step 3: Crawl to Furniture
- Look for sturdy furniture (heavy chair, couch bed)
- Crawl slowly toward it
- Take breaks if needed
- Don't rush

Step 4: Place Hands on Furniture
- Put both hands on seat of chair or bed
- Get one foot forward (stronger leg)
- Keep other knee on ground
- Position like you're proposing

Step 5: Push Up
- Push down on furniture with hands
- Push up with front leg
- Slowly straighten to standing
- Hold onto furniture until steady

Step 6: Sit and Rest
- Turn carefully
- Sit on furniture
- Rest for several minutes
- Don't stand up right away

If You Can't Get Up

When to Stop Trying:
- Too weak  
- Pain increases
- Dizzy or short of breath
- Tried twice with no success
- Feel unsafe

What to Do:
1. Call for help (phone, medical alert device)
2. If no phone nearby, try to get to one by crawling/sliding
3. If trapped, call out for neighbors
4. Stay warm—pull rug, clothes, towels over you
5. Try to slide on flat surface
6. Keep moving limbs to maintain circulation

If You're Alone Without Phone

Prevention is critical:
- Carry phone always
- Medical alert system
- Cordless phone in every room
- Voice-activated devices ("Alexa, call for help")

If trapped:
- Bang on floor/walls to alert neighbors
- If near window, try to attract attention
- Move every 20 minutes to prevent pressure sores
- Stay calm, someone will check on you

After Getting Up

Don't immediately resume activities:
1. Sit for 5-10 minutes
2. Check yourself for injuries
3. Drink water
4. Call someone to let them know
5. Consider calling doctor
6. Write down what happened

Practice This Technique

When you're well:
- Practice getting down to floor and up (with supervision)
- Know which furniture is sturdy enough
- Identify best path from each room
- Build strength and confidence

Practice locations:
- Bedroom (practice getting to bed)
- Living room (practice with different furniture)
- Bathroom (if safe to practice)

Tools That Help

Getting up aids:
- Step stool strategically placed
- Grab bars on walls
- Sturdy furniture at floor level throughout home

Long-Lie Syndrome

Danger of staying down too long:
- After 1 hour: Risk of pressure sores begins, dehydration worsens
- After several hours: Rhabdomyolysis (muscle breakdown from prolonged pressure)
- Hypothermia in cold environments (hours)
- Aspiration risk if unable to move
- Psychological trauma

This is why:
- Medical alert systems save lives
- Regular check-in calls important
- Neighbors should know to check
- Must be able to call for help

Teaching Others

Family/caregivers should know:
- Never try to lift you alone (injury risk to both)
- Call for help if they can't assist you safely
- Two-person assist technique if needed
- When to call 911

Special Situations

Bathroom Falls
- May be wet, slippery
- Less room to maneuver
- Often no close sturdy furniture
- Don't try to get up if wet—wait for help

Outdoor Falls
- Ground may be uneven
- Less sturdy "furniture"
- Cold/hot weather concerns
- Call for help rather than risk further injury

At Night
- Turn on lights first if possible
- Take extra time
- Vision worse
- May be groggy

Preventing the Fear Cycle

After getting up:
- Pride in successful technique
- Recognize you CAN recover
- Don't let fear paralyze you
- Use experience to prevent next fall

Remember

Getting up safely is a skill you hope never to use, but one worth knowing. Practice when you're well so the movements are familiar if needed.

Never feel you "should" be able to get up if you can't. Calling for help is the smart, safe choice.

The biggest danger isn't the fall—it's lying on the floor too long. Always have a way to call for help.

If you've fallen once and struggled to get up, strongly consider a medical alert system. It could save your life.

pages.title: Introduction
pages.content:
Introduction

If you do fall, knowing what to do can prevent injury and complications. This final section prepares you to respond effectively and learn from the experience.

Why This Section Matters

After a fall:
- Immediate response matters
- Getting help quickly is critical
- Medical evaluation important even if you feel fine
- Each fall is a chance to prevent the next one

What This Section Covers

1. When to call 911
2. How to get up safely if you can
3. When to call your doctor
4. What to watch for after a fall
5. Preventing the next fall

Remember

Falls aren't failures—they're medical events that require proper response. Having a plan reduces panic and improves outcomes.

pages.title: How to Prevent the Next Fall
pages.content:
How to Prevent the Next Fall

Every fall offers lessons. Using those lessons to prevent future falls is critical for maintaining your independence and safety.

Why This Matters

The statistics are stark:
- After one fall, your risk of falling again doubles
- 50-60% of people who fall will fall again within a year
- Each subsequent fall increases injury risk

But: Targeted interventions after a fall can reduce repeat falls by 30-50%.

Immediate Actions (Within 1 Week)

1. Detailed Fall Analysis

Ask yourself:
- Where exactly did I fall?
- What time of day?
- What was I doing?
- What did I trip on or what made me lose balance?
- How was I feeling before the fall?
- Had I just taken medication?
- What was the lighting like?
- What shoes was I wearing?

Write it down—memory fades quickly.

2. Fix the Immediate Hazard

If you tripped:
- Remove the object
- Repair the flooring
- Mark the step edge
- Improve lighting
- Change your path

If you lost balance:
- Was there something to hold onto? Add grab bar
- Rushing? Slow down, allow more time
- Dizzy? Call doctor about medications

3. Report to Doctor

Schedule appointment within days:
- Bring written fall details
- Medication list
- Questions about causes

Short-Term Actions (Within 1 Month)

4. Comprehensive Home Safety Review

Go room by room:
- Use checklist from earlier lessons
- Fix everything, not just where you fell
- Falls can happen anywhere

Priority fixes:
- Remove ALL throw rugs (don't just "be more careful")
- Add grab bars in bathroom
- Improve lighting everywhere
- Clear clutter permanently

5. Medical Evaluation

Ensure you get:
- Complete fall risk assessment
- Gait and balance testing
- Vision check
- Medication review
- Blood work if indicated (B12, thyroid, etc.)

6. Start Exercise Program

Physical therapy or evidence-based program:
- Otago exercises
- Tai Chi class
- Balance and strength training
- Commit to 12 weeks minimum

Research shows: Exercise started after a fall reduces future falls by 35-40%.

7. Update Footwear

Replace:
- Shoes with worn soles
- Backless slippers
- Smooth-soled shoes

Get:
- Proper athletic/walking shoes
- Non-slip indoor shoes
- Ice cleats if winter

8. Consider Assistive Devices

If evaluation shows you need them:
- Cane (proper height, training on use)
- Walker
- Grab bars
- Raised toilet seat
- Shower chair

Don't resist—they enable independence

Medium-Term Actions (1-3 Months)

9. Vision and Hearing Check

Schedule:
- Comprehensive eye exam
- New glasses if prescription changed
- Cataract evaluation if applicable
- Hearing test

10. Medication Optimization

Work with doctor/pharmacist:
- Reduce number of medications if possible
- Switch to safer alternatives
- Adjust doses
- Better timing of doses

11. Build Strength and Balance

Continue exercise religiously:
- Track progress
- Increase difficulty gradually
- Join group class for motivation
- Make it part of daily routine

12. Address Fear of Falling

If fear is limiting you:
- Talk to doctor
- Consider counseling
- Join support group
- Gradual re-exposure to activities
- Build confidence through supervised practice

Long-Term Strategies (Ongoing)

13. Maintain Exercise

Forever, not just 12 weeks:
- Balance and strength decline without maintenance
- Benefits disappear within weeks of stopping
- Make it a lifelong habit like brushing teeth

14. Regular Medical Monitoring

Schedule:
- Annual fall risk assessment
- Medication reviews every 6 months
- Vision checks yearly
- Balance testing to track progress

15. Environmental Vigilance

As you age, home needs change:
- Reassess safety yearly
- Make new modifications as needed
- Don't let clutter accumulate

16. Social Engagement

Stay active:
- Social isolation increases fall risk
- Activity maintains function
- Mental stimulation important
- Group exercise provides accountability

Behavioral Changes

Slow Down
Rushing is a major fall cause:
- Allow extra time for everything
- Don't jump up to answer phone/door
- Plan ahead to avoid rushing

Use Lights

Even if you "know" the space:
- Turn on lights BEFORE entering room
- Use nightlights
- Never navigate in darkness

Ask for Help
With:
- Heavy loads
- Reaching high shelves
- Tasks that make you unsteady
- Anything that feels unsafe

Plan Movements
Think before acting:
- How will I get there safely?
- Do I need support?
- Is this worth theland risk?
- Can I do this differently?

Medication Adherence

If prescribed new medications or changes:
- Take as directed
- Note any dizziness/balance changes
- Don't stop without consulting doctor
- Set reminders

Technology Aids

Medical Alert System
Strongly consider after any fall:
- Fall detection models auto-call
- GPS-enabled work anywhere
- Two-way voice communication
- Monthly cost $30-50

Worth it for:
- Living alone
- History of falls
- Anyone at high risk
- Peace of mind

Home Monitoring
- Motion sensors
- Smart home devices
- Video doorbells
- Automated lighting

Tracking Progress

Monitor improvements:
- Balan

pages.title: What to Watch for After a Fall
pages.content:
What to Watch for After a Fall

Even if you feel fine immediately after a fall, some injuries and complications appear hours or days later. Knowing what to watch for can save your life.

First 24-48 Hours: Critical Watch Period

Head Injury Symptoms (Can Be Delayed)

Watch for:
- Worsening headache
- Increasing confusion
- Nausea or vomiting
- Drowsiness or difficulty staying awake
- Slurred speech
- Vision changes
- Unequal pupil size
- Clear fluid from nose/ears
- Personality changes

Especially concerning if:
- You're on blood thinners
- Hit your head (even without losing consciousness)
- Age 65+

Action: Call 911 or go to ER immediately

Fractures That Aren't Obvious

Hip fractures can sometimes be walked on initially:
- Pain that worsens over hours
- Groin or thigh pain
- Difficulty bearing weight
- Shortened or rotated leg

Wrist/arm fractures:
- Increasing swelling
- Can't use hand normally
- Severe pain with movement

Rib fractures:
- Pain with deep breathing
- Pain that worsens
- Shortness of breath

Action: See doctor same day or go to ER

Internal Bleeding

Particularly if on blood thinners:
- Increasing bruising
- Bruises appearing in new locations
- Unusual bruise colors (very dark)
- Swelling
- Lightheadedness
- Rapid heartbeat
- Confusion

Action: Call doctor immediately or go to ER

Days to Weeks After Fall

Delayed Pain
New or worsening pain days later:
- Muscle soreness normal for 2-3 days
- Pain increasing past day 3 = problem
- New pain appearing

Action: Call doctor

Reduced Mobility
Difficulty returning to normal function:
- Still limping after 3 days
- Can't do usual activities
- Range of motion limited
- Weakness persisting

Action: Request physical therapy evaluation

Psychological Effects

Common after falls:
- Fear of falling again
- Anxiety about activities
- Avoiding movements
- Social withdrawal
- Depression

Action: Tell doctor—these are treatable

Normal vs. Concerning

Normal After a Fall
- Soreness for 2-3 days
- Minor bruising
- Feeling shaken up
- Mild stiffness
- Fatigue for a day

NOT Normal
- Increasing pain
- Swelling that worsens
- New symptoms appearing
- Can't return to normal activities in 3-5 days
- Ongoing fear limiting life

Specific Conditions to Monitor

If You Have Osteoporosis
Higher fracture risk:
- Even "small" falls can cause fractures
- Compression fractures may not be obvious
- Back pain could indicate vertebral fracture

Watch for:
- New or worsening back pain
- Height loss
- Stooped posture
- Difficulty breathing (if rib fracture)

If You Take Blood Thinners

Warfarin, Eliquis, Xarelto, Pradaxa:

Extra vigilance needed:
- Bleeding can be delayed
- Bruising develops more easily
- Brain bleeding may not show symptoms immediately

Watch for:
- Any headache
- Confusion
- Unusual bruising
- Blood in urine/stool
- Prolonged bleeding from cuts

If You Have Diabetes
Slower healing:
- Check skin breaks daily
- Watch for infection
- Keep wounds clean
- Report non-healing areas

If You're on Steroids
Bone fragility and poor healing:
- Higher fracture risk
- Slower recovery
- More likely to need imaging

Monitoring Checklist

Daily for First Week
- □ Pain level (scale 1-10)
- □ Swelling changes
- □ Mobility/function
- □ New symptoms
- □ Appetite and sleep
- □ Mood changes

When to Escalate Care

Same day:
- Significant pain increase
- New neurological symptoms
- Difficulty breathing
- Signs of infection (warmth, redness, fever)

Within 2-3 days:
- Not improving as expected
- Can't return to activities
- Persistent pain
- Balance still poor

Infection Risk

Skin breaks from fall:
- Clean wound immediately
- Keep covered
- Watch for redness, warmth, swelling
- Red streaking from wound = emergency
- Fever may indicate infection

UTI risk (if spent time on floor):
- Burning with urination
- Urgent, frequent urination
- Confusion (in older adults)

Deconditioning Risk

"Post-Fall Syndrome:"
- Fear leads to reduced activity
- Muscle atrophy from inactivity begins in days
- Further increases fall risk

Prevention:
- Return to activities as soon as safe
- Physical therapy if needed
- Address fear through counseling/support
- Don't let one fall stop you from living

Emotional Recovery

Normal reactions:
- Temporary fear
- Hypervigilance
- Replaying the fall
- Worry about recurrence

Seek help if:
- Fear paralyzing you
- Avoiding all activities
- Depression
- Social isolation
- Sleep disturbance lasting > 2 weeks
- Panic attacks

Long-Term Monitoring

After any fall, track:
- Near-falls or balance changes
- Medication effects
- Home hazards you've noticed
- Activities you're avoiding

Share at next doctor visit

Cognitive Changes

Fall + head impact can cause:
- Memory problems
- Difficulty concentrating
- Personality changes
- Confusion

Don't dismiss as "just aging"—report to doctor

Creating a Monitoring Plan

Before you fall (ideally):
- Know your baseline
- Understand your medications
- Have doctor's number programmed
- Know when urgent care or ER appropriate

pages.title: When to Call 911
pages.content:
When to Call 911

Some falls require immediate emergency care. Know when to call 911 and when you can wait to see your doctor.

ALWAYS Call 911 If:

Serious Injuries
- Head injury with loss of consciousness (even brief)
- Severe headache after head impact
- Confusion or altered mental status
- Suspected broken bones (severe pain, deformity, can't move limb)
- Hip fracture: Can't stand, severe groin/hip pain
- Large open wounds or heavy bleeding
- Severe pain anywhere

Medical Emergencies Causing Fall
- Chest pain or pressure
- Difficulty breathing
- Slurred speech or facial drooping (stroke signs)
- Weakness on one side of body
- Seizure
- Severe dizziness with vomiting
- Loss of consciousness

Can't Get Up
- Tried safe techniques but unable to rise
- Lying on floor more than 15-20 minutes
- No one to help you
- Feel weak or injured

Signs of Serious Head Injury

Call 911 if you hit your head and have:
- Loss of consciousness
- Severe headache
- Repeated vomiting
- Confusion or memory loss
- Unequal pupils
- Clear fluid from nose or ears
- Sleepiness/difficulty staying awake
- Slurred speech

When You Can Wait

See doctor soon (within 24 hours) if:
- Minor bruising or soreness
- Small cuts (not bleeding heavily)
- You got up OK and feel mostly fine
- Mild headache without other symptoms
- Second or third fall recently

What to Tell 911

Be ready to report:
1. "I've fallen and need help"
2. Your location (address, apartment number)
3. Your injuries
4. Whether you can move
5. Medical conditions
6. Medications (especially blood thinners)
7. Whether you're alone

If You Take Blood Thinners

Warfarin (Coumadin), apixaban (Eliquin), rivaroxaban (Xarelto), dabigatran (Pradaxa):

Call 911 for ANY head injury, even if you feel fine:
- Blood thinners increase bleeding risk
- Brain bleeding can be delayed
- May not have immediate symptoms
- Medical evaluation essential

Special Considerations

Living Alone
Before a fall:
- Medical alert system
- Phone within reach at all times
- Neighbors know to check on you
- Schedule check-in calls

After a fall:
- Call for help even if you think you're OK
- Don't minimize injuries
- Better safe than sorry

If Someone Falls in Front of You

Don't rush to move them:
1. Check if they're conscious and breathing
2. Call 911 if serious injury suspected
3. Keep them still if neck/back injury possible
4. Cover with blanket while waiting
5. Reassure them
6. Don't give food or water

Common Mistakes

Don't:
- Try to "tough it out"
- Refuse ambulance due to cost (health more important)
- Minimize symptoms to avoid "bothering" anyone
- Wait to "see how you feel tomorrow"
- Let embarrassment delay calling for help

Cost Concerns

If worried about ambulance cost:
- Your life is worth more than the bill
- Medicare covers emergency transport
- Many areas have payment plans
- Some injuries get much more expensive if untreated

Remember

When in doubt, call 911. Emergency responders would rather check you and find you're OK than have you seriously injured at home alone.

Brain injuries and hip fractures can initially seem minor but have severe consequences. Don't try to determine severity yourself.

There's no shame in falling or needing help. Quick, appropriate response can prevent complications and save your life.

Minutes matter with stroke, heart attack, and serious bleeding. Don't delay.

pages.title: When to Call Your Doctor
pages.content:
When to Call Your Doctor

Even if you don't need emergency care, most falls warrant a call to your doctor. Evaluation can prevent future falls and catch hidden injuries.

Always Call Your Doctor After:

Any Fall
Even if you feel fine:
- Document the fall
- Identify cause
- Prevent recurrence
- May reveal underlying problem

Don't wait for your next appointment—call within 24-48 hours.

Multiple Falls
If you've fallen 2+ times in 6 months:
- Indicates significant fall risk
- Comprehensive evaluation needed
- May need physical therapy
- Medication review essential

Near-Falls
Frequent close calls are warning signs:
- Catching yourself on furniture often
- Feeling you're about to fall
- Stumbling regularly
- Balance getting worse

What to Tell Your Doctor

Fall Details
- When: Date and time
- Where: Location and surface  
- What were you doing: Activity before fall
- How did you fall: Forward, backward, to side
- Did you trip or just lose balance
- Any warning: Dizziness, weakness, black-out
- Injuries sustained

Symptoms After Fall
- Pain (where, how severe)
- Swelling or bruising
- Difficulty moving
- Headache
- Dizziness
- Confusion
- Weakness

Pattern Recognition
- Time of day
- Related to medications
- Specific activities
- Environmental factors

Scenarios Requiring Doctor Visit

Hit Your Head
Even without loss of consciousness:
- Especially if on blood thinners
- Developing headache
- Any confusion
- Persistent symptoms

Note: Some brain bleeding shows up days later

Increasing Pain
- Worsening over time
- Not improving in 2-3 days
- Interfering with function
- Night pain

Difficulty Walking After Fall
- Limping
- Can't bear weight
- Severe pain with movement
- Swelling in joint

Fall Related to Medical Symptoms
- Fell because of dizziness
- Blacked out or felt faint
- Chest pain before fall
- Shortness of breath
- Palpitations
- Weakness

Medication-Related Falls
- Fell after new medication
- Fell after dose change
- Unusually drowsy or dizzy
- Multiple medications

What Your Doctor Will Do

Initial Evaluation
Medical history:
- Details of fall(s)
- Previous falls
- Medications review
- Chronic conditions
- Recent changes

Physical Examination:
- Check for injuries
- Blood pressure (sitting, standing)
- Heart rhythm
- Neurological exam
- Gait and balance assessment

Testing
May include:
- Blood work (anemia, thyroid, B12, glucose)
- ECG (heart rhythm)
- X-rays if indicated
- Vision screening
- Cognitive assessment

Interventions
Doctor may:
- Adjust medications
- Order physical therapy
- Refer to specialists
- Recommend home safety evaluation
- Prescribe assistive devices
- Order additional testing

Follow-Up Appointments

Expect:
- Recheck in 2-4 weeks
- Assess interventions
- Monitor progress
- Adjust plan as needed

Your responsibilities:
- Complete recommended actions
- Track falls/near-falls
- Report new symptoms
- Attend physical therapy if ordered

Questions to Ask Your Doctor

1. "Why do you think I fell?"
2. "What can we do to prevent it happening again?"
3. "Do my medications increase my fall risk?"
4. "Should I see a physical therapist?"
5. "Do I need any tests?"
6. "When should I come back?"
7. "What warning signs should I watch for?"
8. "Should I stop any activities?"

If Doctor Dismisses Your Concerns

Some doctors may say "falls are normal with aging"—this is FALSE.

If not taken seriously:
- Be assertive: "I'm concerned and would like a thorough evaluation"
- Request physical therapy referral
- Ask for fall risk assessment
- Consider second opinion
- Document falls and bring written log

Virtual vs. In-Person Visit

Telehealth appropriate for:
- Initial discussion
- Review of minor injuries
- Medication review
- Follow-up after interventions

In-person needed for:
- First fall evaluation
- Possible fractures
- Balance/gait testing
- Physical examination
- After head injury

Specialist Referrals

Physical Therapy
Most beneficial referral:
- Gait and balance training
- Strength exercises
- Home safety recommendations
- 6-8 weeks, 1-2x/week typically

Cardiology
If falls related to:
- Irregular heartbeat
- Fainting
- Chest pain
- Palpitations

Neurology
If falls related to:
- Stroke symptoms
- Parkinson's signs
- Severe dizziness/vertigo
- Weakness or numbness

Ophthalmology
If vision contributing:
- Cataracts
- Glaucoma
- Macular degeneration
- Significant vision loss

Podiatry
If foot problems:
- Peripheral neuropathy
- Foot pain affecting gait
- Need for orthotics

Insurance and Coverage

Medicare covers:
- Fall risk assessments
- Physical therapy (with prescription)
- Some durable medical equipment
- Specialist visits

Many insurances cover:
- Annual wellness visits
- Preventive services
- Home health (if qualified)

Keeping Records

Maintain fall diary:
- Date and time
- Circumstances
- Injuries
- What happened after
- Doctor visits
- Recommendations

Bring to appointments:
- Fall log
- Medication list
- Questions written down
- Family member for support/memory

Emergency Department vs
